Lines.Text: remove the plastic covering , located on the left side of the bike , by pulling the piece straight off the bike .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic covering, located on the left side of the bike, by pulling the piece straight off the bike.

Lines.Text: the tool box is located under the panel .
using the key to the motorbike , unlock the tool box .
remove the plastic bag inside holding the tools needed for basic maintenance for the motorbike .

Steps.Text_raw: The tool box is located under the panel. Using the key to the motorbike, unlock the tool box. Remove the plastic bag inside holding the tools needed for basic maintenance for the motorbike.

Lines.Text: using the allen wrench , remove the screws on both sides of the bike seat .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the allen wrench, remove the screws on both sides of the bike seat.

Lines.Text: pull the rear of the seat upwards .
pull the seat backwards to remove it from the bike .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the rear of the seat upwards. Pull the seat backwards to remove it from the bike.

Lines.Text: using the screwdriver , remove the screw holding the plastic cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the screwdriver, remove the screw holding the plastic cover.

Lines.Text: pull the cover off the battery and remove the fuse box from the cover .
place the fuse box over to the side right of the bike . do not disconnect the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the cover off the battery and remove the fuse box from the cover. Place the fuse box over to the side right of the bike.  Do not disconnect the wires.

Lines.Text: using the screwdriver , remove the ground wire ( negative ( - ) cable ) from the battery .
place the wire over the left side of the bike .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the screwdriver, remove the ground wire (negative (-) cable) from the battery. Place the wire over the left side of the bike.

Lines.Text: also using the screwdriver , remove the positive ( + ) cable from the battery .
place the wire over the right side of the bike .
do not let the red ( + ) and black ( - ) wires touch

Steps.Text_raw: Also using the screwdriver, remove the positive (+) cable from the battery. Place the wire over the right side of the bike. Do not let the red(+) and black(-) wires touch

Lines.Text: remove the battery from the bike by pulling upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery from the bike by pulling upwards.

Title: How to change the oil and replace the oil filter in a Suzuki DR650 SE

Lines.Text: remove oil drain plug and let all oil drain from the engine . now remove oil filter cover and take out the old filter .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove oil drain plug and let all oil drain from the engine. Now remove oil filter cover and take out the old filter.

Lines.Text: clean out the oil filter reservoir and put in the new oil filter . replace the filter cover and screw back on tightly . also replace the oil drain plug .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean out the oil filter reservoir and put in the new oil filter. Replace the filter cover and screw back on tightly. Also replace the oil drain plug.

Lines.Text: remove the oil cap and use your funnel to pour in the oil . watch the glass oil fill level to see how much has been put in . once full , put the oil cap back on . ( 2.5 quarts with oil filter , 2.4 w/o filter . )

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the oil cap and use your funnel to pour in the oil. Watch the glass oil fill level to see how much has been put in. Once full, put the oil cap back on. (2.5 quarts with oil filter, 2.4 w/o filter.)

Lines.Text: now that everything is replaced , start the bike up to make sure you have no leaks and see that everything is running smoothly .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that everything is replaced, start the bike up to make sure you have no leaks and see that everything is running smoothly.

Lines.Text: flip the bike over so that only the handle bars and the seat are touching the ground

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the bike over so that only the handle bars and the seat are touching the ground

Lines.Text: using the wrench , loosen the bolts shown by placing the wrench on the bolt so that it is on tight and rotate counterclockwise . it may be hard at first , but as the bolt loosens it will get easier .
now that the bolts are loose you may remove the wheel from the bike .
you may remove the bolts and washers , but this is not necessary to complete the replacement .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the wrench, loosen the bolts shown by placing the wrench on the bolt so that it is on tight and rotate counterclockwise. It may be hard at first, but as the bolt loosens it will get easier. Now that the bolts are loose you may remove the wheel from the bike. You may remove the bolts and washers, but this is not necessary to complete the replacement.

Lines.Text: wedge a screwdriver between the tire and the rim to pry it over the tire over the rim as shown . part of the tire should now be on top of the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Wedge a screwdriver between the tire and the rim to pry it over the tire over the rim as shown. Part of the tire should now be on top of the rim.

Lines.Text: use a second screwdriver and repeat step 3 to create a four to six inch lip where the tire overlaps the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a second screwdriver and repeat step 3 to create a four to six inch lip where the tire overlaps the rim.

Lines.Text: place your fingers in between where the tire is already overlapping the rim and pry out the rest of the tire so that the whole tire overlaps the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Place your fingers in between where the tire is already overlapping the rim and pry out the rest of the tire so that the whole tire overlaps the rim.

Lines.Text: beginning with the nozzle , remove the damaged inner tube by pulling it out from in between the tire and the rim . continue to pull out the rest of the tube .

Steps.Text_raw: Beginning with the nozzle, remove the damaged inner tube by pulling it out from in between the tire and the rim. Continue to pull out the rest of the tube.

Lines.Text: to put the new tube in the tire , begin by wedging the tube in between the tire and the rim . make sure that you start with pushing the nozzle through the hole in the rim as shown . then , continue to push the rest of the tube through the gap between the tire and the rim until the tube is no longer visible .
if the inner tube has a cap over the nozzle you'll have to remove it before you can pull it out of the rim . just use your fingers to rotate the cap counterclockwise until it comes off .

Steps.Text_raw: To put the new tube in the tire, begin by wedging the tube in between the tire and the rim. Make sure that you start with pushing the nozzle through the hole in the rim as shown. Then, continue to push the rest of the tube through the gap between the tire and the rim until the tube is no longer visible. If the inner tube has a cap over the nozzle you'll have to remove it before you can pull it out of the rim. Just use your fingers to rotate the cap counterclockwise until it comes off.

Lines.Text: now just wedge the tire back in between the edges of the rim so that it is back to it's original position . then place the tire back on the fork and tighten it .
make sure you do all this before pumping up the tire because the tire will not fit in between the brake pads if it's fully inflated .

Steps.Text_raw: Now just wedge the tire back in between the edges of the rim so that it is back to it's original position. Then place the tire back on the fork and tighten it. Make sure you do all this before pumping up the tire because the tire will not fit in between the brake pads if it's fully inflated.

Lines.Text: disconnect the rear brake cable

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the rear brake cable

Lines.Text: flip the bike over so that it is resting on the seat and handlebars .
use an adjustable wrench to remove the nuts on both sides of the wheel that hold the wheel to the frame .
lift the tire away from the frame and chain .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the bike over so that it is resting on the seat and handlebars. Use an adjustable wrench to remove the nuts on both sides of the wheel that hold the wheel to the frame. Lift the tire away from the frame and chain.

Lines.Text: insert one tire lever under the tire and hook it onto a spoke . insert the other tire lever next to the first and slide it along the rim to remove one side of the tire from the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert one tire lever under the tire and hook it onto a spoke.  Insert the other tire lever next to the first and slide it along the rim to remove one side of the tire from the rim.

Lines.Text: starting at the valve , pull the inner tube out of the gap between the rim and the tire .

Steps.Text_raw: Starting at the valve, pull the inner tube out of the gap between the rim and the tire.

Lines.Text: pull the tire away from the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the tire away from the rim.

Lines.Text: flip the bike over so it is balanced and resting on the handlebar and the bike seat .
using a socket screwdriver with a hex adapter , loosen the bolt that is holding the kickstand and bracket in place .
this may require a moderate amount of strength . make sure you have the proper hex adapter as to not strip the bolt .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the bike over so it is balanced and resting on the handlebar and the bike seat. Using a socket screwdriver with a hex adapter, loosen the bolt that is holding the kickstand and bracket in place. This may require a moderate amount of strength. Make sure you have the proper hex adapter as to not strip the bolt.

Lines.Text: once the bolt is loose , unscrew it the rest of the way by hand .
remove the bolt . there should now be three separate pieces : the bolt , the bracket , and the kickstand .
make sure to note the position of the bracket before you remove the bolt completely

Steps.Text_raw: Once the bolt is loose, unscrew it the rest of the way by hand. Remove the bolt. There should now be three separate pieces: the bolt, the bracket, and the kickstand. Make sure to note the position of the bracket before you remove the bolt completely

Lines.Text: position the bike so you are facing the braking mechanism of the front wheel .
locate the brake calipers . push the calipers together to relieve the brake tension . unhook the brake wire from the metal tube in your left hand .
locate the brake pad .
using a socket screwdriver with a hex adapter , loosen the nut holding the brake pad in place .
repeat for both brake pads .

Steps.Text_raw: Position the bike so you are facing the braking mechanism of the front wheel. Locate the brake calipers. Push the calipers together to relieve the brake tension. Unhook the brake wire from the metal tube in your left hand. Locate the brake pad. Using a socket screwdriver with a hex adapter, loosen the nut holding the brake pad in place. Repeat for both brake pads.

Lines.Text: next , take the nut completely off of the bolt .
there are 5 washers per brake pad so be sure not to misplace any .
it helps to place the nut and washers in order to make reassembly easier .
remove the three washers in between the nut and caliper . these will be referred to as the outside washers .
next remove the brake pad from the caliper and remove the two washers sitting in between the caliper and the break pad . these will be referred to as the inside washers .

Steps.Text_raw: Next, take the nut completely off of the bolt. There are 5 washers per brake pad so be sure not to misplace any. It helps to place the nut and washers in order to make reassembly easier. Remove the three washers in between the nut and caliper. These will be referred to as the outside washers. Next remove the brake pad from the caliper and remove the two washers sitting in between the caliper and the break pad. These will be referred to as the inside washers.

Lines.Text: take your new brake pad and place the two inside washers on the bolt and slide them all the way to the pad . the one closest to the caliper should have one rounded edge that faces away from the caliper surface .
feed the bolt through the elongated hole on the caliper with the brake facing toward the centerline of the bike .
next feed the outside washers onto the bolt . the rounded washer should be placed first with the rounded edge away from the caliper .
finally screw the nut onto the end of the bolt and tighten the nut enough to stay on but still allowing the brake pad to slide up and down in the oval shaped hole in the caliper .
repeat these procedures for both sides .

Steps.Text_raw: Take your new brake pad and place the two inside washers on the bolt and slide them all the way to the pad. The one closest to the caliper should have one rounded edge that faces away from the caliper surface. Feed the bolt through the elongated hole on the caliper with the brake facing toward the centerline of the bike. Next feed the outside washers onto the bolt. The rounded washer should be placed first with the rounded edge away from the caliper. Finally screw the nut onto the end of the bolt and tighten the nut enough to stay on but still allowing the brake pad to slide up and down in the oval shaped hole in the caliper. Repeat these procedures for both sides.

Lines.Text: make sure the top of the pad is facing up .
the brake pad should have a subtle curve and should be aligned so that the curve of the brake pad matches the curve of the wheel .
slide the break pad to the correct height in the caliper so that the pad is making contact only with the rim of the bike .
holding the brake pad in place with one hand , tighten the bolt until snug . this should not require a great amount of force , but you should not be able to wiggle the brake pad after tightening .
repeat these procedures for both sides .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the top of the pad is facing up. The brake pad should have a subtle curve and should be aligned so that the curve of the brake pad matches the curve of the wheel. Slide the break pad to the correct height in the caliper so that the pad is making contact only with the rim of the bike. Holding the brake pad in place with one hand, tighten the bolt until snug. This should not require a great amount of force, but you should not be able to wiggle the brake pad after tightening. Repeat these procedures for both sides.

if a damper unmounts , it was not installed correctly . repeat the previous step for any unmounted dampers .

when reinstalling the case top shell , be careful not to pinch any wires .

Title: DJI Phantom H3-2D GoPro Camera Installation

Lines.Text: press down on battery door release tab to flip the battery door open .

Steps.Text_raw: Press down on battery door release tab to flip the battery door open.

Lines.Text: pull out the battery pack .
avoid pulling on the battery wires , excess stress may break the wires , damage the power connectors , or crack the internal solder joints .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the battery pack. Avoid pulling on the battery wires, excess stress may break the wires, damage the power connectors, or crack the internal solder joints.

Lines.Text: pull the two halves of the xt60 power connector apart .
it's a tight fit , so be careful not to hit your drone or yank on the cables when it releases !

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the two halves of the XT60 power connector apart. It's a tight fit, so be careful not to hit your drone or yank on the cables when it releases!

Lines.Text: silver-topped propeller collets unscrew counter-clockwise
black-topped propeller collets unscrew clockwise

Steps.Text_raw: Silver-topped propeller collets unscrew counter-clockwise Black-topped propeller collets unscrew clockwise

Lines.Text: '''for propellors with silver collets : ''' use a 12 mm wrench or socket to loosen silver collets in the '''counter-clockwise''' direction .
once free , unscrew and remove the collet .

Steps.Text_raw: '''For propellors with silver collets:''' Use a 12 mm wrench or socket to loosen silver collets in the '''counter-clockwise''' direction. Once free, unscrew and remove the collet.

Lines.Text: '''for propellors with black collets : ''' use a 12 mm wrench or socket to loosen black collets in the '''clockwise''' direction .
once free , unscrew and remove the collet .

Steps.Text_raw: '''For propellors with black collets:''' Use a 12 mm wrench or socket to loosen black collets in the '''clockwise''' direction. Once free, unscrew and remove the collet.

Lines.Text: gently press down the motor shaft and lift the propeller up to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently press down the motor shaft and lift the propeller up to remove it.

Lines.Text: after removing all four propellors , flip the drone over .
remove the following screws from the underside of the drone :
twelve 2.0 mm hex screws
four phillips 0 screws

Steps.Text_raw: After removing all four propellors, flip the drone over. Remove the following screws from the underside of the drone: Twelve 2.0 mm hex screws Four Phillips #0 screws

Lines.Text: loosen the cable from the plastic landing gear .
unplug the magnetometer molex connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the cable from the plastic landing gear. Unplug the magnetometer molex connector.

Lines.Text: lift up on the top portion of the shell and set it on its side .
'''do not '''attempt to fully remove the case . the gps and magnetometer cables connect the top shell to the rest of the phantom , be careful not to stress or break these cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up on the top portion of the shell and set it on its side. '''Do not '''attempt to fully remove the case. The GPS and Magnetometer cables connect the top shell to the rest of the Phantom, be careful not to stress or break these cables.

Lines.Text: lift the gps cable molex connector up out of its socket on the main board .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the GPS cable molex connector up out of its socket on the main board.

Lines.Text: gently pull the slack of the magnetometer cable through the case bottom shell .
the case top shell should now have enough slack to work on the interior of the phantom .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull the slack of the magnetometer cable through the case bottom shell. The case top shell should now have enough slack to work on the interior of the Phantom.

Lines.Text: twist the molex and cable as shown to prepare it for insertion through the case bottom shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the molex and cable as shown to prepare it for insertion through the case bottom shell.

Lines.Text: insert the molex connector through one of the landing gear holes and case bottom shell .
pull the cable through .

this is a really tight fit , take your time and avoid damaging the molex connector or cable . we found that gently rocking the molex connector back and forth through the hole eventually wiggled it through .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the molex connector through one of the landing gear holes and case bottom shell. Pull the cable through. This is a really tight fit, take your time and avoid damaging the molex connector or cable. We found that gently rocking the molex connector back and forth through the hole eventually wiggled it through.

Lines.Text: place the h3-2 d mounting bracket on the bottom side of the phantom .
line up the mounting holes and screw in the two bolts to secure the mounting bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the H3-2D mounting bracket on the bottom side of the Phantom. Line up the mounting holes and screw in the two bolts to secure the mounting bracket.

Lines.Text: twist the other end of the g8 cable molex connector as shown in order to plug in the h3-2 d gimbal .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the other end of the G8 cable molex connector as shown in order to plug in the H3-2D gimbal.

Lines.Text: pass the g8 molex connector through the side of the h3-2 d gimbal .
plug in and firmly secure the connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Pass the G8 molex connector through the side of the H3-2D gimbal. Plug in and firmly secure the connector.

Lines.Text: pull the gimbal wire through the case bottom shell and plug in the connector to the g8 plug on the mainboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the gimbal wire through the case bottom shell and plug in the connector to the G8 plug on the mainboard.

Lines.Text: place the gimbal on the mount with the front facing the same side as the battery cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the gimbal on the mount with the front facing the same side as the battery cover.

Lines.Text: mount the four rubber dampers on the gimbal to the mounting bracket .
pinch two sides of the rubber dampers and press it into the mounting bracket holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Mount the four rubber dampers on the gimbal to the mounting bracket. Pinch two sides of the rubber dampers and press it into the mounting bracket holes.

Lines.Text: confirm the dampers are installed correctly by twisting them at least 180 degrees .
if a damper unmounts , it was not installed correctly . repeat the previous step for any unmounted dampers .

Steps.Text_raw: Confirm the dampers are installed correctly by twisting them at least 180 degrees. If a damper unmounts, it was not installed correctly. Repeat the previous step for any unmounted dampers.

Lines.Text: pull the excess slack in the gimbal cable up into the body of the phantom .
when reinstalling the case top shell , be careful not to pinch any wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the excess slack in the gimbal cable up into the body of the Phantom. When reinstalling the case top shell, be careful not to pinch any wires.

Lines.Text: line up the gopro camera with the pins on the gimbal mount .
press the gopro camera firmly against the gimbal and ensure a snug fit .

Steps.Text_raw: Line up the GoPro camera with the pins on the gimbal mount. Press the GoPro camera firmly against the gimbal and ensure a snug fit.

Lines.Text: place the securing bracket over the camera and line up the bolt holes .
secure the two mounting screws with a phillips 0 driver .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the securing bracket over the camera and line up the bolt holes. Secure the two mounting screws with a Phillips #0 driver.

Subject: GoPro Camera

Title: Removing DJI Phantom 2 Vision+ Case Top Shell

Lines.Text: pinch the top and bottom tabs of the battery case , pull the battery straight out to remove it .

the metal connectors form a stiff mechanical connection with the battery , you will need quite a bit of force to remove the battery . hold the phantom vision+ with one hand and remove the battery with the other .

Steps.Text_raw: Pinch the top and bottom tabs of the battery case, pull the battery straight out to remove it. The metal connectors form a stiff mechanical connection with the battery, you will need quite a bit of force to remove the battery. Hold the Phantom Vision+ with one hand and remove the battery with the other.

Lines.Text: determine if the propellor is clockwise or counter-clockwise rotating .
each arm is labeled with a rotation icon that shows the direction of propellor rotation .
if this icon is missing or you can't read it , you can determine the direction of rotation by examining the propellor .

a clockwise rotating propellor pushes air down while rotating clockwise , and the opposite is true for a counter-clockwise rotating propellor , and the propellor blade slopes up in the direction of rotation .

Steps.Text_raw: Determine if the propellor is clockwise or counter-clockwise rotating. Each arm is labeled with a rotation icon that shows the direction of propellor rotation. If this icon is missing or you can't read it, you can determine the direction of rotation by examining the propellor. A clockwise rotating propellor pushes air down while rotating clockwise, and the opposite is true for a counter-clockwise rotating propellor, and the propellor blade slopes up in the direction of rotation.

Lines.Text: loosen a clockwise rotating propeller by holding the motor with one hand and spinning the propellor clockwise .
remove the propellor .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen a clockwise rotating propeller by holding the motor with one hand and spinning the propellor clockwise. Remove the propellor.

Lines.Text: loosen a counter-clockwise rotating propeller by holding the motor with one hand and spinning the propellor counter-clockwise .
remove the propellor .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen a counter-clockwise rotating propeller by holding the motor with one hand and spinning the propellor counter-clockwise. Remove the propellor.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws from the underside of the phantom :
twelve 2.0 mm hex bolts
four phillips 00 screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws from the underside of the Phantom: Twelve 2.0 mm hex bolts Four Phillips #00 screws

Lines.Text: gently lift up the top shell case .
'''do not''' attempt to fully remove the top shell . the gps cable is still attached to the mainboard , avoid lifting the case too high or you may damage this connection .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift up the top shell case. '''Do not''' attempt to fully remove the top shell. The GPS cable is still attached to the mainboard, avoid lifting the case too high or you may damage this connection.

Lines.Text: the gps cable molex connector is located on the backside of the mainboard , near the battery opening .
pull the gps connector straight up out of its socket .
lift the top shell case up and remove it from the body of the phantom .

Steps.Text_raw: The GPS cable molex connector is located on the backside of the mainboard, near the battery opening. Pull the GPS connector straight up out of its socket. Lift the top shell case up and remove it from the body of the Phantom.

the motor spin direction is dependent on the order of the wires , and may not match this image exactly . if you forgot the order , check the arm directly opposite for reference .

when replacing a motor , be sure to solder the new motor in following the same wire color order as when you removed it .
the motor spin direction is dependent on the order of the wires , and may not match this image exactly . if you forgot the order , check the arm directly opposite for reference .

Lines.Text: remove the four 2 mm hex motor bolts .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 2mm hex motor bolts.

Lines.Text: remove the motor from the motor mount .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motor from the motor mount.

Lines.Text: cut the zip-tie securing the signal and power cables .
unplug the esc signal cable molex connector from the esc .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the zip-tie securing the signal and power cables. Unplug the ESC signal cable molex connector from the ESC.

Lines.Text: desolder the esc ground and voltage wires from the mainboard .
be careful not to melt the plastic case bottom shell with your soldering iron or damage any electronic components .
you can remove in-the-way cables by unplugging them and moving them aside . this will protect them from the warning above .
be sure to plug these cables back in before reassembling your phantom 2.

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the ESC ground and voltage wires from the mainboard. Be careful not to melt the plastic case bottom shell with your soldering iron or damage any electronic components. You can remove in-the-way cables by unplugging them and moving them aside. This will protect them from the warning above. Be sure to plug these cables back in before reassembling your Phantom 2.

Lines.Text: remove the two esc securing screws .
the clear plastic led cover will either drop from the underside or need to be loosened with a plastic spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two ESC securing screws. The clear plastic LED cover will either drop from the underside or need to be loosened with a plastic spudger.

Lines.Text: with the esc no longer secured to the airframe , lift it up and remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: With the ESC no longer secured to the airframe, lift it up and remove it.

Lines.Text: peel off double sided tape and apply to one side of the broken hull .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off double sided tape and apply to one side of the broken hull.

Lines.Text: cut the tape with scissors as close to the shape of the broken hull as possible .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the tape with scissors as close to the shape of the broken hull as possible.

Lines.Text: peel off the other side of the tape and stick the two sides together .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off the other side of the tape and stick the two sides together.

Lines.Text: remove the foam body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the foam body.

Lines.Text: disconnect the battery by pulling the two red wires apart .
remove the battery by releasing the battery retaining straps .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the battery by pulling the two red wires apart. Remove the battery by releasing the battery retaining straps.

Lines.Text: turn the drone upside down .
the cover is held on by plastic tape . peel off the tape and use a spudger to remove the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the drone upside down. The cover is held on by plastic tape. Peel off the tape and use a spudger to remove the back cover.

Lines.Text: using a spudger , separate the connector for the downward camera .
remove the camera from the body by pulling it off the foam body .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, separate the connector for the downward camera. Remove the camera from the body by pulling it off the foam body.

Lines.Text: use a spudger to release the black retaining clip . then disconnect the connector to the sensors .
use tweezers to carefully remove the ribbon from the connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a spudger to release the black retaining clip. Then  disconnect the connector to the sensors. Use tweezers to carefully remove the ribbon from the connector.

Lines.Text: remove the four 8 mm torx screws with a t6 bit .
remove the four 8 mm phillips head screws with a 00 bit .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 8mm torx screws with a T6 bit. Remove the four 8mm philips head screws with a PH00 bit.

Lines.Text: carefully pull the secondary board from the mainboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pull the secondary board from the mainboard.

Lines.Text: turn the drone right side up
remove the usb connector from the battery retaining straps .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the drone right side up Remove the USB connector from the battery retaining straps.

Lines.Text: release the rubber clip holding the usb and battery power cable to the body .

Steps.Text_raw: Release the rubber clip holding the USB and battery power cable to the body.

Lines.Text: avoid using sharp tools near the battery .
push the usb and power cable through the battery panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Avoid using sharp tools near the battery. Push the USB and power cable through the battery panel.

Lines.Text: turn the drone upside down again .
use a spudger to release the connector and carefully remove the ribbon .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the drone upside down again. Use a spudger to release the connector and carefully remove the ribbon.

Lines.Text: lift the mainboard up so that you can access the back .
disconnect the first connector with the white wires using a nylon spudger .
disconnect the second connector with the red and black wires using a spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the mainboard up so that you can access the back. Disconnect the first connector with the white wires using a nylon spudger. Disconnect the second connector with the red and black wires using a spudger.

Lines.Text: the mainboard is now fully detached and can be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: The mainboard is now fully detached and can be removed.

Lines.Text: using a nylon spudger , peel off the four pieces of plastic securing the frame to the body .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a nylon spudger, peel off the four pieces of plastic securing the frame to the body.

Lines.Text: carefully maneuver the four arms of the drones central cross until it detaches from the body by pulling apart the foam surrounding the arms .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully maneuver the four arms of the drone’s central cross until it detaches from the body by pulling apart the foam surrounding the arms.

Lines.Text: the central cross can now be removed and replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: The central cross can now be removed and replaced.

be careful as these clips can fly off and can be difficult to find .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the small retaining clip using a plastic opening tool. Be careful as these clips can fly off and can be difficult to find.

Lines.Text: the propeller , gear , and rod can be removed by simply lifting them off the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: The propeller, gear, and rod can be removed by simply lifting them off the motor.

Lines.Text: disconnect the connector at the bottom of the motor assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the connector at the bottom of the motor assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the three 5 mm screws on the top of the motor assembly with a 00 bit .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three 5mm screws on the top of the motor assembly with a PH00 bit.

Lines.Text: remove the three 5 mm screws on the bottom again using a 00 bit .
the three screws from the top are different from the three screws on the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three 5mm screws on the bottom again using a PH00 bit. The three screws from the top are different from the three screws on the bottom.

Lines.Text: carefully wiggle out the motor assembly out of the arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully wiggle out the motor assembly out of the arm.

Lines.Text: firmly grasp both sides of the battery connector and pull them apart .
grip the battery and slide it out of the quadcopter body .
do not pull on the wires . this could damage the battery or flight controller .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grasp both sides of the battery connector and pull them apart. Grip the battery and slide it out of the quadcopter body. Do not pull on the wires. This could damage the battery or flight controller.

Lines.Text: orient the quadcopter so the propellers are on the bottom .
remove the rubber shock absorbers from the motor mounts by hand .

Lines.Text: use the prop removal tool to pry the propellers off the motors .
each propeller and motor arm is labeled either a or b corresponding to whether the motor spins clockwise or counterclockwise . with the quad oriented with the front facing towards you :
a propellers are on the front left and back right motors .
b propellers are on the front right and back left motors .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the prop removal tool to pry the propellers off the motors. Each propeller and motor arm is labeled either "A" or "B" corresponding to whether the motor spins clockwise or counterclockwise. With the quad oriented with the front facing towards you: "A" propellers are on the front left and back right motors. "B" propellers are on the front right and back left motors.

Lines.Text: use the wire cutter to remove any customized or aftermarket modifications holding the body together .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the wire cutter to remove any customized or aftermarket modifications holding the body together.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 000 screwdriver to remove the three screws securing the lower body to the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #000 screwdriver to remove the three screws securing the lower body to the frame.

Lines.Text: carefully apply upward pressure on one of the motor arms while bending the body downwards to snap the lower body armpice out of place .
repeat this step for all four arms . the lower body will separate from the main frame after snapping the fourth arm out of place .
you may need to bend the arm quite a bit to snap it out . this is a durability feature that allows the x4 to crumple in a crash without breaking .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully apply upward pressure on one of the motor arms while bending the body downwards to snap the lower body armpice out of place. Repeat this step for all four arms. The lower body will separate from the main frame after snapping the fourth arm out of place. You may need to bend the arm quite a bit to snap it out. This is a durability feature that allows the X4 to "crumple" in a crash without breaking.

Lines.Text: use a soldering iron and solder wick to desolder the four motors from the control board .
if the connection holds even after removing the solder from the joint , gently pull up on the wire while applying heat to the joint until the wire separates from the pcb .
the motor wires are in either black-white or red-blue pairs .

caution : overheating the pcb can damage the traces , making it difficult or impossible to reconnect the components later on . do not apply too much heat to the board ; these traces are especially delicate due to their small size .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a soldering iron and solder wick to desolder the four motors from the control board. If the connection holds even after removing the solder from the joint, gently pull up on the wire while applying heat to the joint until the wire separates from the PCB. The motor wires are in either black-white or red-blue pairs. CAUTION: Overheating the PCB can damage the traces, making it difficult or impossible to reconnect the components later on. Do not apply too much heat to the board; these traces are especially delicate due to their small size.

Lines.Text: using a technique similar to desoldering the motor wires , disconnect the leds from the control board .
the led connections use less solder than the motor joints , so solder wick is optional but not required for this step .
when reassembling the quadcopter , remember the led's have red positive leads and bronze negative leads .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a technique similar to desoldering the motor wires, disconnect the LEDs from the control board. The LED connections use less solder than the motor joints, so solder wick is optional but not required for this step. When reassembling the quadcopter, remember the LED's have red positive leads and bronze negative leads.

Lines.Text: use the tweezers to unthread the motor and led wires from the quadcopter arms .
after unthreading all eight bundles of wires , the leds and motors are ready to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tweezers to unthread the motor and LED wires from the quadcopter arms. After unthreading all eight bundles of wires, the LEDs and motors are ready to remove.

Lines.Text: use the tweezers to push the motors out of their housings .

both the motor mounts and motors themselves have a small size variance . if it's difficult to push a motor out , ensure the wires are not caught on the frame and gently apply more force from the bottom until the motor begins to slide .
once the motor is mostly out of the motor mount , grip it from the top and pull it straight out .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tweezers to push the motors out of their housings. Both the motor mounts and motors themselves have a small size variance. If it's difficult to push a motor out, ensure the wires are not caught on the frame and gently apply more force from the bottom until the motor begins to slide. Once the motor is mostly out of the motor mount, grip it from the top and pull it straight out.

Lines.Text: remove the leds using the spudger to widen their housing and nudge them up .
to free an led from its housing , insert the spudger into the top section of the gap in the plastic revealing the side of the led .
simultaneously twist the spudger to widen the housing while pushing the led up and out of the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the LEDs using the spudger to widen their housing and nudge them up. To free an LED from its housing, insert the spudger into the top section of the gap in the plastic revealing the side of the LED. Simultaneously twist the spudger to widen the housing while pushing the LED up and out of the frame.

Lines.Text: unlike the motors which had colored wiring to differentiate between cw and ccw spin , both the blue and red leds have a red positive leads and a bronze negative lead . upon closer inspection , it looks like the heat shrink on the postive lead matches the led color .

Steps.Text_raw: Unlike the motors which had colored wiring to differentiate between CW and CCW spin, both the blue and red LEDs have a red positive leads and a bronze negative lead. Upon closer inspection, it looks like the heat shrink on the postive lead matches the LED color.

Lines.Text: use the 000 driver to remove the two screws securing the flight controller to the frame .
after removing both screws , the flight controller drops freely out of the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the PH000 driver to remove the two screws securing the flight controller to the frame. After removing both screws, the flight controller drops freely out of the frame .

Lines.Text: the hubsan x4 's flight controller ( aka control board ) has a handful of neat components that keep the quadcopter in the air :
hubsan hbs002 processor
invensense itg-3050 integrated triple-axis gyroscope
16.000 mhz quartz crystal oscillator
3210 ap 3-axis accelerometer
a7105 2.4 ghz wireless module

Steps.Text_raw: The Hubsan X4's Flight Controller (aka Control Board) has a handful of neat components that keep the quadcopter in the air: Hubsan HBS002 Processor Invensense ITG-3050 Integrated Triple-Axis Gyroscope 16.000 MHz Quartz Crystal Oscillator 3210AP 3-Axis Accelerometer A7105 2.4GHz Wireless Module

Lines.Text: all done ! to reassemble your x4 , follow these steps in the reverse order .
this is a good opportunity to test all your leds and motors and switch out any faulty components .

Steps.Text_raw: All done! To reassemble your X4, follow these steps in the reverse order. This is a good opportunity to test all your LEDs and motors and switch out any faulty components.

Lines.Text: remove the 4 mm hex screw securing the back of the seat .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 4 mm Hex screw securing the back of the seat.

Lines.Text: remove the two 10 mm hex head bolts , one on either side of the seat .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 10 mm hex head bolts, one on either side of the seat.

Lines.Text: push the seat towards the front of the bike and lift it up .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the seat towards the front of the bike and lift it up.

Title: DJI Phantom 2 Vision Plus GPS Signal Improvement Technique

Lines.Text: remove the following screws from the underside of the phantom :
twelve 2.0 mm hex bolts
four phillips 00 screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws from the underside of the Phantom: Twelve 2.0 mm hex bolts Four Phillips #00 screws

Lines.Text: gently lift up the top shell case .
'''do not''' attempt to fully remove the top shell . the gps cable is still attached to the mainboard , avoid lifting the case too high or you may damage this connection .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift up the top shell case. '''Do not''' attempt to fully remove the top shell. The GPS cable is still attached to the mainboard, avoid lifting the case too high or you may damage this connection.

Lines.Text: the gps cable molex connector is located on the backside of the mainboard , near the battery opening .
pull the gps connector straight up out of its socket .
lift the top shell case up and remove it from the body of the phantom .

Steps.Text_raw: The GPS cable molex connector is located on the backside of the mainboard, near the battery opening. Pull the GPS connector straight up out of its socket. Lift the top shell case up and remove it from the body of the Phantom.

Title: Repairing a Hole in a Fiber Glass Jet Ski Body

Toolbox.Name: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: for this jet ski the hood is detachable so it can be removed and worked on while it is off . this allows us to work on both sides of the hole .
the hole is highlighted on the jet ski by the red circle .

Steps.Text_raw: For this jet ski the hood is detachable so it can be removed and worked on while it is off. This allows us to work on both sides of the hole. The hole is highlighted on the jet ski by the red circle.

Lines.Text: begin by sanding both sides of the hole surface with the rough sandpaper until the larger pieces of old fiberglass are smooth .
use the fine sandpaper in succession with the rough to make the surface as smooth as possible .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by sanding both sides of the hole surface with the rough sandpaper until the larger pieces of old fiberglass are smooth. Use the fine sandpaper in succession with the rough to make the surface as smooth as possible.

Lines.Text: use the acetone and a paper towel to clean both sides of the hole and be sure to remove any dirt from the surface .
the surface must be very clean in order for the resin to bond well .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the Acetone and a paper towel to clean both sides of the hole and be sure to remove any dirt from the surface. The surface must be very clean in order for the resin to bond well.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: on the back side of the hole take your fiber glass mat and size out the piece of material needed to cover the hole .
include some extra space around the hole , as shown by the red square , for additional support .
once you have sized the material , cut out multiple pieces with the scissors for additional layers .

Steps.Text_raw: On the back side of the hole take your fiber glass mat and size out the piece of material needed to cover the hole. Include some extra space around the hole, as shown by the red square, for additional support. Once you have sized the material, cut out multiple pieces with the scissors for additional layers.

Lines.Text: it's time to mix the resin and hardener together . read the specific instructions on the back of the container to get the accurate ratio of resin to hardener .
rubber gloves are needed at this point . the resin can be very sticky .
use a mixing stick to swirl the resin once you have added the hardener . the resin is now active and ready to be applied .

Steps.Text_raw: It's time to mix the resin and hardener together. Read the specific instructions on the back of the container to get the accurate ratio of resin to hardener. Rubber gloves are needed at this point. The resin can be very sticky. Use a mixing stick to swirl the resin once you have added the hardener. The resin is now active and ready to be applied.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: with the throw away paint brush begin to apply the resin to the back side of the hole directly on the cleaned surface .
after the resin is on , take one of the fiberglass pieces you cut out earlier and place it over the hole onto the resin .
continuing with the brush , apply more resin onto the fiberglass until it is entirely soaked .

Steps.Text_raw: With the throw away paint brush begin to apply the resin to the back side of the hole directly on the cleaned surface. After the resin is on, take one of the fiberglass pieces you cut out earlier and place it over the hole onto the resin. Continuing with the brush, apply more resin onto the fiberglass until it is entirely soaked.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: after the first layer has been entirely soaked in resin , the next layer can be placed on top of it .
soak this layer in resin as well and repeat if you wish to apply more than two layers .

Steps.Text_raw: After the first layer has been entirely soaked in resin, the next layer can be placed on top of it. Soak this layer in resin as well and repeat if you wish to apply more than two layers.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: allow the layers to dry for the recommended amount of time listed of the back of the resin container .
make sure to feel the material once dry to confirm the resin hardened properly .

Steps.Text_raw: Allow the layers to dry for the recommended amount of time listed of the back of the resin container. Make sure to feel the material once dry to confirm the resin hardened properly.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: once dry , it is time to move onto the front side of the hole .
use the sharpie to carefully outline the shape of the hole and then cut out the shape with your scissors , again making multiple layers .
it is important to outline the shape because you want the end result to be flush with the existing surface unlike the back side of the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Once dry, it is time to move onto the front side of the hole. Use the sharpie to carefully outline the shape of the hole and then cut out the shape with your scissors, again making multiple layers. It is important to outline the shape because you want the end result to be flush with the existing surface unlike the back side of the hole.

Lines.Text: after you have again mixed your resin , begin by applying a small layer to the inside of the hole only .
place your fiberglass piece onto the resin in the hole , and then continue to coat the layer in resin until soaked .
continue this process with all layers until resin surface is flush with existing surface .
again , let the resin dry for the designated period of time provided on the back of the resin container .

Steps.Text_raw: After you have again mixed your resin, begin by applying a small layer to the inside of the hole only. Place your fiberglass piece onto the resin in the hole, and then continue to coat the layer in resin until soaked. Continue this process with all layers until resin surface is flush with existing surface. Again, let the resin dry for the designated period of time provided on the back of the resin container.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Lines.Text: once dry , confirm that the resin has fully hardened .
use the sand paper to sand the resin surface and existing surface to create a seamless finish .
once again , start with the rough sand paper and then finish sanding with the fine .
after sanding , the fiber glass should be flush with the existing surface of the body . at this point feel free to paint over the hole and get back on the lake .

Steps.Text_raw: Once dry, confirm that the resin has fully hardened. Use the sand paper to sand the resin surface and existing surface to create a seamless finish. Once again, start with the rough sand paper and then finish sanding with the fine. After sanding, the fiber glass should be flush with the existing surface of the body. At this point feel free to paint over the hole and get back on the lake.
Tools_extracted: fiber glass resin with fiber glass resin hardener

Title: How To Fix A Loose Bicycle Pedal And Check For Damage

Lines.Text: flip the entire bicycle upside down , balancing the weight on the seat and handle bars .
this will keep the bicycle stable while you work on it .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the entire bicycle upside down, balancing the weight on the seat and handle bars. This will keep the bicycle stable while you work on it.

Lines.Text: you will need an allen wrench or a smart wrench for this repair .
if you are using an allen wrench , insert the head of the wrench into socket located on the pedal arm .
if you are using a smart wrench , place the jaws on the nut located between the pedal and pedal arm .
loosen the pedals by turning the right pedal counterclockwise and the left pedal clockwise .
remove the pedal from the socket .

Steps.Text_raw: You will need an Allen Wrench or a Smart Wrench for this repair. If you are using an Allen Wrench, insert the head of the wrench into socket located on the pedal arm. If you are using a Smart Wrench, place the jaws on the nut located between the pedal and pedal arm. Loosen the pedals by turning the right pedal counterclockwise and the left pedal clockwise. Remove the pedal from the socket.

Lines.Text: check the socket and bolt for rust and worn threads .
if you notice damages like rust or worn threads , you will need to refer to a separate repair guide specific to the type of damage .
if you do not see any damage , continue to step 4.

Steps.Text_raw: Check the socket and bolt for rust and worn threads. If you notice damages like rust or worn threads, you will need to refer to a separate repair guide specific to the type of damage. If you do not see any damage, continue to Step 4.

Lines.Text: place the pedal back in the socket and tighten it until it is secure .
to tighten the pedals , turn the right pedal clockwise and the left pedal counterclockwise .
once you feel resistance , turn the pedal about 1 /8 of a rotation further to properly tighten it .
do not use excessive force when you are tightening the pedal . this can lead to difficulty removing the pedal in the future .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the pedal back in the socket and tighten it until it is secure. To tighten the pedals, turn the right pedal clockwise and the left pedal counterclockwise. Once you feel resistance, turn the pedal about 1/8 of a rotation further to properly tighten it. DO NOT use excessive force when you are tightening the pedal. This can lead to difficulty removing the pedal in the future.

Lines.Text: use the allen wrench to loosen the allen bolt that keeps the derailleur cable in tension and attached to the derailleur body .
the allen bolt is located near the front sprockets ( gears ) on the opposite side ( the left side of the frame ) .
over-loosening can unthread the bolt from the small nut on the other side , which is hard to get rethreaded . try to avoid backing off much farther than the diameter of the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the Allen wrench to loosen the Allen bolt that keeps the derailleur cable in tension and attached to the derailleur body. The Allen bolt is located near the front sprockets (gears) on the opposite side (the left side of the frame). Over-loosening can unthread the bolt from the small nut on the other side, which is hard to get rethreaded. Try to avoid backing off much farther than the diameter of the cable.

Lines.Text: free the cable from the derailleur body .
depending upon the fit , this may require forcing the cable through the narrow gaps between the derailleur body and the small silver holding plate held by the allen bolt .
depending on the condition of the cable , this may require some cutting of the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Free the cable from the derailleur body. Depending upon the fit, this may require forcing the cable through the narrow gaps between the derailleur body and the small silver holding plate held by the Allen bolt. Depending on the condition of the cable, this may require some cutting of the cable.

Lines.Text: remove the 1 phillips 6 mm screws that hold the shifter casing onto the shifter .
to avoid losing these small parts , use a sandwich container or jar to hold them while you do other things .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the #1 Phillips 6 mm screws that hold the shifter casing onto the shifter. To avoid losing these small parts, use a sandwich container or jar to hold them while you do other things.

Lines.Text: remove the shifter casing ( the top ) from the shifter body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the shifter casing (the top) from the shifter body.

Lines.Text: remove the 0 phillips 6 mm screw attaching the indicator dial onto the shifter mechanism .
remove the indicator dial .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the #0 Phillips 6 mm screw attaching the indicator dial onto the shifter mechanism. Remove the indicator dial.

Lines.Text: free the end of the cable from the shifter .
trick : use pliers or vise grips to hold the cable in front of the shifter mechanism .
downshift while holding the cable .
the end is forced out !

Steps.Text_raw: Free the end of the cable from the shifter. Trick: use pliers or vise grips to hold the cable in front of the shifter mechanism. Downshift while holding the cable. The end is forced out!

Lines.Text: if the cable is not already cut , cut any excessively frayed ends or crimps off the end by the derailleur so the cable can easily be pulled back through the housings .

Steps.Text_raw: If the cable is not already cut, cut any excessively frayed ends or crimps off the end by the derailleur so the cable can easily be pulled back through the housings.

Lines.Text: pull on the shifter end of the cable to pull the cable free of the bike , through the shifter and all the housings .
keep track of all the parts as they come free of the cable !

Steps.Text_raw: Pull on the shifter end of the cable  to pull the cable free of the bike, through the shifter and all the housings. Keep track of all the parts as they come free of the cable!

Lines.Text: push the new cable through the shifter .

to get a better angle into the shifter mechanism or the exit housing , use the upshifter and downshifter to rotate the shifting mechanism , similar to the way downshifting could be used to force out the end in step 6.

Steps.Text_raw: Push the new cable through the shifter. To get a better angle into the shifter mechanism or the exit housing, use the upshifter and downshifter to rotate the shifting mechanism, similar to the way downshifting could be used to force out the end in Step 6.

Lines.Text: continue feeding the new cable through the shifter and through all the housings .
the housings may be easier to feed if held straight until the end is all the way through to avoid catching the end in the bends .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue feeding the new cable through the shifter and through all the housings. The housings may be easier to feed if held straight until the end is all the way through to avoid catching the end in the bends.

Lines.Text: make sure the head of the derailleur cable is properly seated in the shifter mechanism .
pushing against the head while also pulling the cable tight can help check this .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the head of the derailleur cable is properly seated in the shifter mechanism. Pushing against the head while also pulling the cable tight can help check this.

Lines.Text: run the end of the cable around the tightening allen bolt , between the silver holding plate and the derailleur body .

Steps.Text_raw: Run the end of the cable around the tightening Allen bolt, between the silver holding plate and the derailleur body.

Lines.Text: lift the derailleur into position .
pull the derailleur cable tight , while still holding the derailleur in position .
tighten the allen bolt to fix the derailleur cable to the derailleur and hold the derailleur in position .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the derailleur into position. Pull the derailleur cable tight, while still holding the derailleur in position. Tighten the Allen bolt to fix the derailleur cable to the derailleur and hold the derailleur in position.

Lines.Text: check the derailleur placement .
the chain should be roughly centered in the derailleur , so that no extra friction is caused , and that the chain is not unintentionally pushed off the sprocket .
if not in the correct position , reloosen the tightening bolt and redo step 13. this may take several tries .

make sure the shifter is in the same position as the chain . for example , in these pictures the chain is in position 2 , and so is the shifter ( the gears are numbered smallest to biggest ) . otherwise the bike will not be able to properly shift .

Steps.Text_raw: Check the derailleur placement. The chain should be roughly centered in the derailleur, so that no extra friction is caused, and that the chain is not unintentionally pushed off the sprocket. If not in the correct position, reloosen the tightening bolt and redo step 13. This may take several tries. Make sure the shifter is in the same position as the chain. For example, in these pictures the chain is in position 2, and so is the shifter (the gears are numbered smallest to biggest). Otherwise the bike will not be able to properly shift.

Lines.Text: once the derailleur is in the correct position , cut the cable to length , leaving 2 to 3 inches to allow for later adjustment if needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the derailleur is in the correct position, cut the cable to length, leaving 2 to 3 inches to allow for later adjustment if needed.

Lines.Text: place the crimp on the cut end of the cable , making sure to get any loose strands within the crimp as well .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the crimp on the cut end of the cable, making sure to get any loose strands within the crimp as well.

Lines.Text: using vise grips or pliers , clamp down on the crimp and crimp the end of the cable
if done properly , this should prevent any fraying at the end of the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Using vise grips or pliers, clamp down on the crimp and crimp the end of the cable If done properly, this should prevent any fraying at the end of the cable.

Lines.Text: reassemble the shifter , putting back the indicator , the case , and their corresponding screws

Steps.Text_raw: Reassemble the shifter, putting back the indicator, the case, and their corresponding screws

Title: How to Replace Scott Mountain Bike Handlebars

Lines.Text: prop bike upright
unscrew the hex bolts holding the front and rear shifter in place .
use the h4 size hex wrench
repeat for other side of handlebars .

Steps.Text_raw: Prop bike upright Unscrew the hex bolts holding the front and rear shifter in place. Use the H4 size hex wrench Repeat for other side of handlebars.

Lines.Text: slide the shifters toward the center of the handlebars so there is a gap between them and the grips .
repeat for other side of handlebars .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the shifters toward the center of the handlebars so there is a gap between them and the grips. Repeat for other side of handlebars.

Lines.Text: use a flathead screwdriver to wedge a gap between the grip and the handlebars .
twist grip around until it comes off of handlebar .
repeat for other side of handlebars .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flathead screwdriver to wedge a gap between the grip and the handlebars. Twist grip around until it comes off of handlebar. Repeat for other side of handlebars.

Lines.Text: slide the shifters off of the end of the handlebars .
let them hang on the bike .
repeat for other side of handlebars .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the shifters off of the end of the handlebars. Let them hang on the bike. Repeat for other side of handlebars.

Lines.Text: unscrew the hex bolts holding the center bracket in place .
use h3 hex wrench .
place center bracket and hex screws off to the side . they will be needed in the next step .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the hex bolts holding the center bracket in place. Use H3 hex wrench. Place center bracket and hex screws off to the side. They will be needed in the next step.

Lines.Text: attach new handlebars and screw the center bracket back in place .
make sure that handlebars are centered .

Steps.Text_raw: Attach new handlebars and screw the center bracket back in place. Make sure that handlebars are centered.

Lines.Text: slide the shifters back onto the handlebars so that the numbers are upright .
do not screw them back in place yet .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the shifters back onto the handlebars so that the numbers are upright. Do not screw them back in place yet.

Lines.Text: slide the handlebar grips back onto the ends of the handlebars .
slide the shifters back against the grips and screw them into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the handlebar grips back onto the ends of the handlebars. Slide the shifters back against the grips and screw them into place.

Subject: Scott Mountain Bike Handlebars

Lines.Text: unscrew both nuts on opposite sides of the rear wheel with the 15 mm wrench until the wheel loosens from the bike frame .
loosen the nuts with the 15 mm wrench and continue unscrewing the nuts with your hands .
push the rear wheel forward until enough slack is given on the chain .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew both nuts on opposite sides of the rear wheel with the 15 mm wrench until the wheel loosens from the bike frame. Loosen the nuts with the 15 mm wrench and continue unscrewing the nuts with your hands. Push the rear wheel forward until enough slack is given on the chain.

Lines.Text: with the slack previously made , remove the chain off the chainring .
touching the chain isn't dangerous , but it will be dirty .

Steps.Text_raw: With the slack previously made, remove the chain off the chainring. Touching the chain isn't dangerous, but it will be dirty.

Lines.Text: locate chainring , the gear connected to the pedals .
place the spanner tool on the backside of the 6.5 mm chainring bolt . the spanner will be used to keep the bolts in place while unscrewing them on the opposite sides .
on the chainring there will be one bolt facing the opposite direction , usually the bolt blocked by the pedal . adjust for this by swapping use of the hex key and spanner tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate chainring, the gear connected to the pedals. Place the spanner tool on the backside of the 6.5 mm chainring bolt. The spanner will be used to keep the bolts in place while unscrewing them on the opposite sides. On the chainring there will be one bolt facing the opposite direction, usually the bolt blocked by the pedal. Adjust for this by swapping use of the hex key and spanner tool.

Lines.Text: with the spanner tool on one side of the chainring , use a 5 mm hex key to remove the chainring bolts on the opposite side .
repeat with the rest of the bolts .

Steps.Text_raw: With the spanner tool on one side of the chainring, use a 5 mm hex key to remove the chainring bolts on the opposite side. Repeat with the rest of the bolts.

Lines.Text: use clean paper towels to wipe off the chainring bolts . make sure to wipe off all the dirt and grease you can .
clean thoroughly within the threads .

Steps.Text_raw: Use clean paper towels to wipe off the chainring bolts. Make sure to wipe off all the dirt and grease you can. Clean thoroughly within the threads.

Lines.Text: now that the chainring bolts are clean , apply a pea-sized amount of grease to each bolt .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the chainring bolts are clean, apply a pea-sized amount of grease to each bolt.

Lines.Text: use your fingers to evenly spread a coat the grease around the entire bolt .
if the chainring bolts contain rust , it is recommended to replace the bolts with a new set .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers to evenly spread a coat the grease around the entire bolt. If the chainring bolts contain rust, it is recommended to replace the bolts with a new set.

Lines.Text: using the 5 mm allen wrench , check if the bolt on the backside of the caliper is snug .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the 5mm allen wrench,check if the bolt on the backside of the caliper is snug.

Lines.Text: if your brake caliper is still tightened , loosen the cable bolt with a 5 mm allen wrench to take tension off the caliper .

Steps.Text_raw: If your brake caliper is still tightened, loosen the cable bolt with a 5mm Allen wrench to take tension off the caliper.

Lines.Text: check if the braking pads are contacting the rim in desired locations .
both pads are loosened the same way .
for the left caliper pad , marked in the red circle , loosen the bolt with a 4 mm allen wrench so the pad can be adjusted .
align the bottom edge of the pad with the bottom edge of the braking surface and then tighten .
for the right caliper pad , marked in the yellow circle , loosen the bolt with a 4 mm allen wrench so the pad can be adjusted .
align the top edge of the pad with the top edge of the braking surface and then tighten .

Steps.Text_raw: Check if the braking pads are contacting the rim in desired locations. Both pads are loosened the same way. For the left caliper pad, marked in the red circle, loosen the bolt with a 4mm Allen wrench so the pad can be adjusted. Align the bottom edge of the pad with the bottom edge of the braking surface and then tighten. For the right caliper pad, marked in the yellow circle, loosen the bolt with a 4mm Allen wrench so the pad can be adjusted. Align the top edge of the pad with the top edge of the braking surface and then tighten.

Lines.Text: check if your brake cable is inside the groove on the two plates ( marked in the red cirlce ) that hold the brake cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Check if your brake cable is inside the groove on the two plates (marked in the red cirlce) that hold the brake cable.

Lines.Text: if the adjustment lever is not turned down , turn it down .

Steps.Text_raw: If the adjustment lever is not turned down, turn it down.

Lines.Text: squeeze the caliper until both sides are about 1 mm from the rim .
while still squeezing , pull down the slack on the wire and tension the wire by bolting it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Squeeze the caliper until both sides are about 1mm from the rim. While still squeezing, pull down the slack on the wire and tension the wire by bolting it down.

Lines.Text: fine tune the brake calipers by using the barrel adjuster .
counter clockwise turns open the calipers and clockwise turns close the calipers .

Steps.Text_raw: Fine tune the brake calipers by using the barrel adjuster. Counter clockwise turns open the calipers and clockwise turns close the calipers.

Lines.Text: make the brake pads equidistant from the rim by adjusting the tiny bolt on top of the caliper with a 3 mm allen wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: Make the brake pads equidistant from the rim by adjusting the tiny bolt on top of the caliper with a 3mm Allen wrench.

Lines.Text: check if the brakes are working properly by squeezing your brake levers .

Steps.Text_raw: Check if the brakes are working properly by squeezing your brake levers.

Title: How to Replace a Rear Brake Cable

Lines.Text: using the smart wrench and socket wrench , remove the nuts that are holding the connector to the old brake line .
after taking apart the connector , slide the screw off the brake line .
the nut may be difficult to remove if it has not been removed for a while .
keep in mind the order the parts came off the connector . this will make reassembly easier .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the smart wrench and socket wrench, remove the nuts that are holding the connector to the old brake line. After taking apart the connector, slide the screw off the brake line. The nut may be difficult to remove if it has not been removed for a while. Keep in mind the order the parts came off the connector. This will make reassembly easier.

Lines.Text: remove the cable housing from its holders .
slide the housing off the brake cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cable housing from its holders. Slide the housing off the brake cable.

Lines.Text: remove the second cable housing from its holder .
unscrew the other end of the housing from the brake .
remove the housing from the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the second cable housing from its holder. Unscrew the other end of the housing from the brake. Remove the housing from the cable.

Lines.Text: apply pressure to the brake to reveal the end of the brake cable .
remove the cable from its holder within the brake .
pull the remaining cable through the brake .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply pressure to the brake to reveal the end of the brake cable. Remove the cable from its holder within the brake. Pull the remaining cable through the brake.

Lines.Text: flip your bike to make the brake housing more visible .
insert the new brake cable into the brake housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip your bike to make the brake housing more visible. Insert the new brake cable into the brake housing.

Lines.Text: slide the cable housing onto the new cable .
re-insert the housing back into its holders .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the cable housing onto the new cable. Re-insert the housing back into its holders.

Lines.Text: slide the rear cable housing onto the new brake cable .
re-insert the housing into its holders .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the rear cable housing onto the new brake cable. Re-insert the housing into its holders.

Lines.Text: slide the screw and washer onto the end of the brake cable .
slide the connector of over the screw and tighten the nut and washer on the other end by hand , so it can slide along the brake cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the screw and washer onto the end of the brake cable. Slide the connector of over the screw and tighten the nut and washer on the other end by hand, so it can slide along the brake cable.

Lines.Text: flip bike back right-side-up .
slide the connector up near the housing holder . about an inch between the connector and holder should be fine .
using the smart wrench and 10 mm socket wrench , tighten the nut so it grips the brake line firmly .
using wire-cutters , cut the extra cable so only about an inch remains .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip bike back right-side-up. Slide the connector up near the housing holder. About an inch between the connector and holder should be fine. Using the smart wrench and 10mm socket wrench, tighten the nut so it grips the brake line firmly. Using wire-cutters, cut the extra cable so only about an inch remains.

Lines.Text: you can recycle the old brake cable for this .
insert the end of the brake cable with a nub into the slot on the rear left brake .
slide the cable onto the slot on the connector .
slide the other end of the cable into the holder on the right rear brake .
pull the cable to clamp down the brakes so they almost touch the rim of the wheel .
tighten the screw so the cable does not come loose .

Steps.Text_raw: You can recycle the old brake cable for this. Insert the end of the brake cable with a "nub" into the slot on the rear left brake. Slide the cable onto the slot on the connector. Slide the other end of the cable into the holder on the right rear brake. Pull the cable to clamp down the brakes so they almost touch the rim of the wheel. Tighten the screw so the cable does not come loose.

Subject: Rear Brake Cable

Lines.Text: this step will be easier if you flip your bicycle upside down , and balance it on the seat and handlebars .
loosen the nuts holding the axle in place using the two wrenches .
unscrew the brake arm from the frame of the bicycle using the screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: This step will be easier if you flip your bicycle upside down, and balance it on the seat and handlebars. Loosen the nuts holding the axle in place using the two wrenches. Unscrew the brake arm from the frame of the bicycle using the screwdriver.

Lines.Text: loosen the nuts holding the axle in the wheel using the wrenches . unscrew the axle , and remove the bearings and brake assembly . set them off to the side on a rag .
when pulling the parts out , arrange them in the order in which you took them out . this way , you don't forget the order .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the nuts holding the axle in the wheel using the wrenches. Unscrew the axle, and remove the bearings and brake assembly. Set them off to the side on a rag. When pulling the parts out, arrange them in the order in which you took them out. This way, you don't forget the order.

Lines.Text: clean the inside of the wheel hub using a paper towel and some wd-40.
be sure to wipe out excess grease and grit .
when done , set the wheel off to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the inside of the wheel hub using a paper towel and some WD-40. Be sure to wipe out excess grease and grit. When done, set the wheel off to the side.

Lines.Text: add some soap to the water in the plastic tub , and mix it around
a small squirt of soap will do . too much soap , and you'll have to deal with excess bubbles .

Steps.Text_raw: Add some soap to the water in the plastic tub, and mix it around A small squirt of soap will do. Too much soap, and you'll have to deal with excess bubbles.

Lines.Text: clean all of the internal parts in the tub using the toothbrush .
you may occasionally have to wipe excess grease and grit off of the toothbrush with a paper towel .
be sure to get all of the areas where the bearings will sit ( see red circles )
also scrub the threads on the sprocket ( see orange line )

Steps.Text_raw: Clean all of the internal parts in the tub using the toothbrush. You may occasionally have to wipe excess grease and grit off of the toothbrush with a paper towel. Be sure to get all of the areas where the bearings will sit (see red circles) Also scrub the threads on the sprocket (see orange line)

Lines.Text: when cleaning the bearings , spin the balls to help remove grit from inside .

Steps.Text_raw: When cleaning the bearings, spin the balls to help remove grit from inside.

Lines.Text: dry the parts using a paper towel .
when dry , set them off to the side on a rag .
be sure to keep them in order

Steps.Text_raw: Dry the parts using a paper towel. When dry, set them off to the side on a rag. Be sure to keep them in order

Lines.Text: reassemble the parts of the bearing and axle assembly which go on the opposite side of the hub from the sprocket . this includes the brake pads and the cone
using your fingers , make sure the bearings are well coated with grease .
make sure to add some grease at key points shown ( red lines ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Reassemble the parts of the bearing and axle assembly which go on the opposite side of the hub from the sprocket. This includes the brake pads and the cone Using your fingers, make sure the bearings are well coated with grease. Make sure to add some grease at key points shown (red lines).

Lines.Text: put the axle and bearings back into the cleaned hub .
make sure that you put the axle in from the side opposite where the sprocket is .

if you don't remember , look at your tire . most tires have an arrow pointing in the direction the wheel turns when you go forward . the axle should go in from the side where the arrow points counter-clockwise

Steps.Text_raw: Put the axle and bearings back into the cleaned hub. Make sure that you put the axle in from the side opposite where the sprocket is. If you don't remember, look at your tire. Most tires have an arrow pointing in the direction the wheel turns when you go forward. The axle should go in from the side where the arrow points counter-clockwise

Lines.Text: gently screw the sprocket into the hub .
screw the bearing race on . make sure not to tighten too much . the sprocket and wheel should still spin easily .
remember to place the bearings in the right spot . the large one is placed as shown by the red line , and the small one as shown by the orange line .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently screw the sprocket into the hub. Screw the bearing race on. Make sure not to tighten too much. The sprocket and wheel should still spin easily. Remember to place the bearings in the right spot. The large one is placed as shown by the red line, and the small one as shown by the orange line.

Lines.Text: replace the wheel onto the bicycle .
don't forget to put the chain around the sprocket !
make sure the wheel is straight relative to the bicycle , and that the chain is relatively taut .
tighten the nuts to hold the wheel in place .
before continuing , spin the wheel and crank the pedals to make sure everything spins smoothly . if not , check to make sure the axle nuts aren't too tight .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the wheel onto the bicycle. Don't forget to put the chain around the sprocket! Make sure the wheel is straight relative to the bicycle, and that the chain is relatively taut. Tighten the nuts to hold the wheel in place. Before continuing, spin the wheel and crank the pedals to make sure everything spins smoothly. If not, check to make sure the axle nuts aren't too tight.

Title: How To Repair A Sticking Mountain Bike Brake Line

Toolbox.Name: park tool cl-1 synthetic blend chain lube with ptfe

Lines.Text: remove the grip from the bike's handle bar .
use short twisting motions . if the grip is really stuck onto the bar , some soapy water can help it come off easier .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the grip from the bike's handle bar. Use short twisting motions. If the grip is really stuck onto the bar, some soapy water can help it come off easier.

Lines.Text: unscrew the hex screw on the brake fixture on the handle bars with the allen wrench .
