once the brake fixture is loose , pull off the fixture form the handle and set aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the hex screw on the brake fixture on the handle bars with the allen wrench. Once the brake fixture is loose, pull off the fixture form the handle and set aside.

Lines.Text: unhook the brake line from the bike's body by sliding the line backwards and pulling up in one motion .
if the brake line is too tight to pull back , you may have to remove the rear tire to let the brake pads move farther .

Steps.Text_raw: Unhook the brake line from the bike's body by sliding the line backwards and pulling up in one motion. If the brake line is too tight to pull back, you may have to remove the rear tire to let the brake pads move farther.

Lines.Text: remove the brake line from the brake assembly you removed in step one .
unscrew the adjustment screw all the way out of the assembly .
push brake line forward and slide the line out of the slot in the brake handle .
check the spring of the brake lever without the line connected . if it does not retract well , you can clean it with soapy water .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the brake line from the brake assembly you removed in step one. Unscrew the adjustment screw all the way out of the assembly. Push brake line forward and slide the line out of the slot in the brake handle. Check the spring of the brake lever without the line connected. If it does not retract well, you can clean it with soapy water.

Lines.Text: to remove the brake line from the rear brake pads . unhook the line from the metal insert .
unscrew the hex bolt with an allen wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the brake line from the rear brake pads. Unhook the line from the metal insert. Unscrew the hex bolt with an allen wrench.

Lines.Text: after you have removed the bike's brake line , take the whole assembly wipe with a soapy water solution to remove rust , dirt , grease and anything else stopping the line from traveling freely .
after removing all of the debris , apply chain oil to another rag and wipe oil evenly onto the line .
careful the line itself could be frayed anywhere due to age and be sharp .

Steps.Text_raw: After you have removed the bike's brake line, take the whole assembly wipe with a soapy water solution to remove rust, dirt, grease and anything else stopping the line from traveling freely. After removing all of the debris, apply chain oil to another rag and wipe oil evenly onto the line. Careful the line itself could be frayed anywhere due to age and be sharp.

Title: How to refurbish performance skateboard bearings

Lines.Text: turn your wrench to the left to remove the wheel nut .
take the wheel off of your trucks by pulling .
keep all nuts and spacers in separated , designated areas .
wear gloves . you are working with messy materials such as gasoline .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn your wrench to the left to remove the wheel nut. Take the wheel off of your trucks by pulling. Keep all nuts and spacers in separated, designated areas. Wear gloves. You are working with messy materials such as gasoline.

Lines.Text: firmly lever the bearing out using your screwdriver .
do not be overly forceful to avoid scratching the bearing .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly lever the bearing out using your screwdriver. Do not be overly forceful to avoid scratching the bearing.

Lines.Text: soak the bearing in a cup with premium gasoline for 5 minutes .
soak each bearing separately so none are lost or dented .

Steps.Text_raw: Soak the bearing in a cup with premium gasoline for 5 minutes. Soak each bearing separately so none are lost or dented.

Lines.Text: take the bearing out of the gasoline and remove one side of the outside plastic locks by applying pressure on the inner ring and prying up .
make sure you can clearly see and access the ball bearings .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the bearing out of the gasoline and remove one side of the outside plastic locks by applying pressure on the inner ring and prying up. Make sure you can clearly see and access the ball bearings.

Lines.Text: use your toothbrush to clean the bearings by using a gentle back and forth scrubbing motion .
rinse the bearing with water and let dry for 5 minutes .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your toothbrush to clean the bearings by using a gentle back and forth scrubbing motion. Rinse the bearing with water and let dry for 5 minutes.

Lines.Text: once dry , pick up your bearings with two fingers and drop 2 drops of skateboard lubricant into the bearing .
spin the bearings immediately to spread the lubricant evenly .

Steps.Text_raw: Once dry, pick up your bearings with two fingers and drop 2 drops of skateboard lubricant into the bearing. Spin the bearings immediately to spread the lubricant evenly.

Lines.Text: use a paper towel to remove excess lubricant .
replace the plastic guard .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a paper towel to remove excess lubricant. Replace the plastic guard.

Title: How to Patch a Hole in a Bicycle Tube

Lines.Text: using the tire lever hook side , hook the inside of the tire . then proceed to remove the first side of the tire from the rim all along the circumference of the rim .
once one side is out , pull the rest of the tire out in the same direction .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the tire lever hook side, hook the inside of the tire. Then proceed to remove the first side of the tire from the rim all along the circumference of the rim. Once one side is out, pull the rest of the tire out in the same direction.

Lines.Text: pull the inner tube away and out of the tire until it is completely detached from the tire .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the inner tube away and out of the tire until it is completely detached from the tire.

Lines.Text: while squeezing the tube with both hands , rotate the tire while keeping an ear to the tube to hear air escaping , which marks the location of the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: While squeezing the tube with both hands, rotate the tire while keeping an ear to the tube to hear air escaping, which marks the location of the hole.

Lines.Text: note : the next portion is about patching the hole so keep the sand paper , rubber cement , and patches nearby .

Steps.Text_raw: NOTE: The next portion is about patching the hole so keep the sand paper, rubber cement, and patches nearby.

Lines.Text: grind the location of the hole slightly until the surface feels a little rough .
next , apply a thin coat of the rubber cement around the hole . the coat of cement should be about the same size as the patch .
for best results wait until the rubber cement is dry to the toucharound three minutes .
finally , peel off the back of the patch , place it over the area of rubber cement with the hole centered , and then apply pressure with thumb until rubber cement is dry .

Steps.Text_raw: Grind the location of the hole slightly until the surface feels a little rough. Next, apply a thin coat of the rubber cement around the hole. The coat of cement should be about the same size as the patch. For best results wait until the rubber cement is dry to the touch—around three minutes. Finally, peel off the back of the patch, place it over the area of rubber cement with the hole centered, and then apply pressure with thumb until rubber cement is dry.

Lines.Text: using one hand to hold the rim , use the other to push one side of the tire back onto the rim .
starting by placing the valve stem into the hole in the rim , begin pushing the tube into and under the tire . then continue all the way around the tire .
a valve stem is the metal/rubber piece that sticks out of a bike tire's tube .

Steps.Text_raw: Using one hand to hold the rim, use the other to push one side of the tire back onto the rim. Starting by placing the valve stem into the hole in the rim, begin pushing the tube into and under the tire. Then continue all the way around the tire. A valve stem is the metal/rubber piece that sticks out of a bike tire's tube.

Lines.Text: once the tube is in , push the second side of the tire into the rim and continue all the way around the rim until the tire is inside the rim .
check both sides once you believe to be done as to make sure that the tire did not slip out of the rim anywhere .
if you have caliper brakes then it is recommended that you place your tire back onto the bike before re-inflating .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the tube is in, push the second side of the tire into the rim and continue all the way around the rim until the tire is inside the rim. Check both sides once you believe to be done as to make sure that the tire did not slip out of the rim anywhere. If you have caliper brakes then it is recommended that you place your tire back onto the bike before re-inflating.

Lines.Text: turn the bike upside down if you don't have a bike stand . this will make it easier to remove the tire .
unfasten the left side of the wheel by pulling the black l shaped lever up with your hands .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the bike upside down if you don't have a bike stand. This will make it easier to remove the tire. Unfasten the left side of the wheel by pulling the black "L" shaped lever up with your hands.

Lines.Text: on the right side , use your hands to unscrew the cap of the axle counterclockwise until it is loose .

Steps.Text_raw: On the right side, use your hands to unscrew the cap of the axle counterclockwise until it is loose.

Lines.Text: push down on the the tire with your hands to remove it from the frame of the bike .
sometimes the axle will get caught in the boxed area . use both of your hands to cautiously push it down harder until the tire comes loose . this may require a fair amount of force .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the the tire with your hands to remove it from the frame of the bike. Sometimes the axle will get caught in the boxed area. Use both of your hands to cautiously push it down harder until the tire comes loose. This may require a fair amount of force.

Lines.Text: slightly loosen the valve bolt counterclockwise with your thumb and index finger .
deflate the tire by pressing down the air valve tip with your finger . use as much pressure as needed to hear the air flowing out of the tube .

Steps.Text_raw: Slightly loosen the valve bolt counterclockwise with your thumb and index finger. Deflate the tire by pressing down the air valve tip with your finger. Use as much pressure as needed to hear the air flowing out of the tube.

Lines.Text: use you thumb and index finger to unscrew the valve nut by rotating it counterclockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Use you thumb and index finger to unscrew the valve nut by rotating it counterclockwise.

Lines.Text: hold the tire lever firmly in your hands and look for the boundary between the tire and the wheel rim . apply great force to the lever until you pry the rim and the tire apart .
you can do this step anywhere along the circumference of the wheel .

with the tip of the lever inserted between the rim and the tire , rotate the lever 90 counterclockwise and fix the lever to the metal spokes using the arrow shaped slot located on the top of the lever .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the tire lever firmly in your hands and look for the boundary between the tire and the wheel rim. Apply great force to the lever until you pry the rim and the tire apart. You can do this step anywhere along the circumference of the wheel. With the tip of the lever inserted between the rim and the tire, rotate the lever 90° counterclockwise and fix the lever to the metal spokes using the arrow shaped slot located on the top of the lever.

Lines.Text: insert an extra tire lever between the tire and the rim .
move the lever along the circumference of the rim to pry the tire apart .
you may attach as many tire levers on the spokes as you feel necessary to make this step easier .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an extra tire lever between the tire and the rim. Move the lever along the circumference of the rim to pry the tire apart. You may attach as many tire levers on the spokes as you feel necessary to make this step easier.

Lines.Text: start removing the tire by unplugging the valve from the rim slot .
remove the rest of the tire and the tube from the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Start removing the tire by unplugging the valve from the rim slot. Remove the rest of the tire and the tube from the rim.

Lines.Text: once you have the tire removed from the rim , place the rim on the truing stand and tighten the stand on the axle using the knob on the side of the stand to make sure the rim is secured on the stand .
raise the calipers on the stand so they are the same height as the rim . you can adjust the height of the calipers using knob on the base of the stand .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have the tire removed from the rim, place the rim on the truing stand and tighten the stand on the axle using the knob on the side of the stand to make sure the rim is secured on the stand. Raise the calipers on the stand so they are the same height as the rim. You can adjust the height of the calipers using knob on the base of the stand.

Lines.Text: adjust the calipers by using the knob directly below them so there is a about a 1 /2 inch gap between the calipers and the walls of the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Adjust the calipers by using the knob directly below them so there is a about a 1/2 inch gap between the calipers and the walls of the rim.

Lines.Text: spin the rim . as the rim is spinning , slowly rotate the knob to move the calipers towards the rim in small increments until one of them begins to make contact with the rim .
take note of the contact spot on the rim . this is where you will make adjustments .

Steps.Text_raw: Spin the rim. As the rim is spinning, slowly rotate the knob to move the calipers towards the rim in small increments until one of them begins to make contact with the rim. Take note of the contact spot on the rim. This is where you will make adjustments.

Lines.Text: add a lubricant to the spoke nipples to allow them to turn easier and make the spoke tighter .
this step is not always necessary ; however , if you are having trouble turning the spoke wrench , it is a good idea to apply the lubricant .

Steps.Text_raw: Add a lubricant to the spoke nipples to allow them to turn easier and make the spoke tighter. This step is not always necessary; however, if you are having trouble turning the spoke wrench, it is a good idea to apply the lubricant.

Lines.Text: loosen the spokes on the side of the tire slightly using the spoke wrench . adjust the spoke directly where the bend was along with 2 or 3 spokes on each side of it . try to keep each adjustment around 1 /4 to 1 /2 of a turn to avoid tightening or loosening a spoke too much .
the nut you are tightening is screwing onto the spoke , so if you turn it counter-clockwise as you are looking down on it , you are tightening the spoke .
go back and tighten the spokes that connect to the opposite side of the tire using the same technique .

as you complete this step , you should see the rim moving in the direction that you are tightening the spokes ; however , you may have to repeat this step many times before the rim is perfectly straight .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the spokes on the side of the tire slightly using the spoke wrench. Adjust the spoke directly where the bend was along with 2 or 3 spokes on each side of it. Try to keep each adjustment around 1/4 to 1/2 of a turn to avoid tightening or loosening a spoke too much. The nut you are tightening is screwing onto the spoke, so if you turn it counter-clockwise as you are looking down on it, you are tightening the spoke. Go back and tighten the spokes that connect to the opposite side of the tire using the same technique. As you complete this step, you should see the rim moving in the direction that you are tightening the spokes; however, you may have to repeat this step many times before the rim is perfectly straight.

Title: How to adjust and maintain 2006 Iron Horse Warrior Rear Derailleur Cables

Lines.Text: first , we need to set the high and low bounds on position that the derailleur can travel to .
shift the rear derailleur so it is in the 8th gear position .
using the phillips head screwdriver , adjust the screw labeled with an h so that the derailleur lines up vertically with the 8th gear ( the smallest one ) .

Steps.Text_raw: First, we need to set the high and low bounds on position that the derailleur can travel to. Shift the rear derailleur so it is in the 8th gear position. Using the phillips head screw driver, adjust the screw labeled with an H so that the derailleur lines up vertically with the 8th gear (the smallest one).

Lines.Text: set the low bound by shifting the rear derailleur to its 1 st gear position . adjust the screw labeled with a l , so the derailleur lines up vertically with the 1 st gear .
if you are unable to get the low bound over far enough by adjusting the screw , try tightening the cable using the adjustment knob found on the shifter itself .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the low bound by shifting the rear derailleur to its 1st gear position. Adjust the screw labeled with a L, so the derailleur lines up vertically with the 1st gear. If you are unable to get the low bound over far enough by adjusting the screw, try tightening the cable using the adjustment knob found on the shifter itself.

Lines.Text: the last thing you need to adjust is the distance the derailleur moves between gears .
shift the derailleur into either the 4th or 5th gear , and adjust the hex screw found on the back of the derailleur to make sure the derailleur lines up vertically with the gear the bike is in .

Steps.Text_raw: The last thing you need to adjust is the distance the derailleur moves between gears. Shift the derailleur into either the 4th or 5th gear, and adjust the hex screw found on the back of the derailleur to make sure the derailleur lines up vertically with the gear the bike is in.

Title: How to adjust the 2006 Iron Horse Warrior front derailleur

Lines.Text: shift the front derailleur to the 1 st position ( smallest cog and closest to the body of the bike )
adjust the low screw with a screwdriver so the derailleur lines up vertically with the 1 st gear .
test your gears by holding your back tire off the ground and pedaling while you shift through your gears . if it is aligned correctly , the chain will not rub on the derailleur .

Steps.Text_raw: Shift the front derailleur to the 1st position (smallest cog and closest to the body of the bike) Adjust the "Low" screw with a screwdriver so the derailleur lines up vertically with the 1st gear. Test your gears by holding your back tire off the ground and pedaling while you shift through your gears. If it is aligned correctly, the chain will not rub on the derailleur.

Lines.Text: shift to 3 rd gear ( the largest cog and farthest from the body of the bike )
adjust the derailleur until it lines up vertically with the 3 rd gear

the same rules apply for this one as when setting the lower bound . however , you want the smallest gap possible between the outer edge of the chain and the guard . the smaller gap will allow your bike to downshift much easier .
the derailleur should be aligned now , but if you are unable to move the derailleur far enough away from the frame , you may need to tighten the cable itself . if so , proceed to step 3.

Steps.Text_raw: Shift to 3rd gear (the largest cog and farthest from the body of the bike) Adjust the derailleur until it lines up vertically with the 3rd gear The same rules apply for this one as when setting the lower bound. However, you want the smallest gap possible between the outer edge of the chain and the guard. The smaller gap will allow your bike to downshift much easier. The derailleur should be aligned now, but if you are unable to move the derailleur far enough away from the frame, you may need to tighten the cable itself. If so, proceed to Step 3.

Lines.Text: this step is only required if you were unable to align the derailleur in step 2
to tighten the cable , place the derailleur in the 1 st gear position . this position requires the least amount of tension on the cable .
loosen the 6 mm hex nut using an allen wrench just enough to allow the cable to come free .
pull the cable using your hands as tight as you can . replace the cable under the screw and tighten the screw by turning it clockwise .
repeat step 2 to set the upper bound on the derailleur . now that the cable is tight , the derailleur will be able to travel further away from the frame of the bike and line up with the 3 rd gear .

Steps.Text_raw: This step is only required if you were unable to align the derailleur in Step 2 To tighten the cable, place the derailleur in the 1st gear position. This position requires the least amount of tension on the cable. Loosen the 6mm hex nut using an Allen wrench just enough to allow the cable to come free. Pull the cable using your hands as tight as you can. Replace the cable under the screw and tighten the screw by turning it clockwise. Repeat Step 2 to set the upper bound on the derailleur. Now that the cable is tight, the derailleur will be able to travel further away from the frame of the bike and line up with the 3rd gear.

Lines.Text: remove the cap covering the crank arm using the 6 mm allen key

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cap covering the crank arm using the 6mm Allen Key

Lines.Text: screw the larger diameter threads on the crank puller into the hole you removed the cap from .
slightly tighten it with an adjustable wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: Screw the larger diameter threads on the crank puller into the hole you removed the cap from. Slightly tighten it with an adjustable wrench.

Lines.Text: tighten the handle on the crank puller until the arm and gears slide off of the axle .

the crank puller works by locking into the threads on the arm and pushing against the isis drive axle to pry the arm and gears off . make sure you are using the correct size crank puller , otherwise this step will not work .
during reassembly , add some grease to the axle to make it easier to remove the arm in the future .

Steps.Text_raw: Tighten the handle on the crank puller until the arm and gears slide off of the axle. The crank puller works by locking into the threads on the arm and pushing against the Isis drive axle to pry the arm and gears off. Make sure you are using the correct size crank puller, otherwise this step will not work. During reassembly, add some grease to the axle to make it easier to remove the arm in the future.

Lines.Text: remove the four 6 mm hex bolts from the small chainring using the 6 mm hex screwdriver . this will allow you to remove the chainring .
when reinstalling , apply a loctite thread compound on the threads to keep them from loosening as you ride . also , make sure the writing on the new chainring faces the frame of the bike .
this chainring has a bolt circle diameter of 64 mm ( bcd 64 ) and 22 teeth ; however , you can replace it with any chainring with a bcd of 64.

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 6mm hex bolts from the small chainring using the 6mm hex screwdriver. This will allow you to remove the chainring. When reinstalling, apply a loctite thread compound on the threads to keep them from loosening as you ride. Also, make sure the writing on the new chainring faces the frame of the bike. This chainring has a bolt circle diameter of 64 mm (BCD 64) and 22 teeth; however, you can replace it with any chainring with a BCD of 64.

Title: Repairing a ripped off cable of a Sigma ATS and STS cyclometer mount
Category: Sigma ATS and STS cyclometer mount

Lines.Text: use your cutter knife to pry open the small cap that hides the inner contacts .
you probably have to go a bit deeper into the plastic as the cap is glued to the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your cutter knife to pry open the small cap that hides the inner contacts. You probably have to go a bit deeper into the plastic as the cap is glued to the casing.

Lines.Text: take the remaining cable and remove some of the thick black insulation as well as some of the thin insulation as shown in the picture .
remove the broken cable by ripping it off carefully or using a soldering iron .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the remaining cable and remove some of the thick black insulation as well as some of the thin insulation as shown in the picture. Remove the broken cable by ripping it off carefully or using a soldering iron.

Lines.Text: use the paper clip to hold the cable at the right position .
solder the prepared cable to the contacts .
remember : the red cable left , the black cable right .
the contacts take up heat of the soldering iron really fast . this can lead to the contacts melting the surrounding plastic . hence , you have to be fast .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the paper clip to hold the cable at the right position. Solder the prepared cable to the contacts. Remember: the red cable left, the black cable right. The contacts take up heat of the soldering iron really fast. This can lead to the contacts melting the surrounding plastic. Hence, you have to be fast.

Lines.Text: apply some glue to the mount and re-attach the cap to the mount .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply some glue to the mount and re-attach the cap to the mount.

Title: How to Use a CO2 Cartridge to Re-Inflate the Rear Wheel of a Road Bike

Toolbox.Name: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Lines.Text: removing the rear wheel of a road bike , generally , is quite easy , but it can be messy if the bike chain has excessive grease .
figure out which tire is flat . in this case , the rear wheel is flat .

Steps.Text_raw: Removing the rear wheel of a road bike, generally, is quite easy, but it can be messy if the bike chain has excessive grease. Figure out which tire is flat. In this case, the rear wheel is flat.
Tools_extracted: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Lines.Text: disengage the brakes .
this will allow the wheel to slide out smoother .

Steps.Text_raw: Disengage the brakes. This will allow the wheel to slide out smoother.

Lines.Text: to easily remove the rear wheel , flip the bike upside down so that it's sitting on the handle bars and seat .

Steps.Text_raw: To easily remove the rear wheel, flip the bike upside down so that it's sitting on the handle bars and seat.

Lines.Text: disengage the quick-release lever to loosen the wheel .
turn the quick-release lever a few times while you hold the cap on the opposite side of the wheel .
don't unscrew the lever or cap too much or else a spring will pop out .
if the spring comes out , place the spring back on the bar and tighten the cap or lever .

Steps.Text_raw: Disengage the quick-release lever to loosen the wheel. Turn the quick-release lever a few times while you hold the  cap on the opposite side of the wheel. Don't unscrew the lever or cap too much or else a spring will pop out. If the spring comes out, place the spring back on the bar and tighten the cap or lever.
Tools_extracted: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Lines.Text: pull the wheel out .
pull the rear shifter into a straight line so the wheel will be able to slide out smoothly .
pull out the wheel with one hand while you hold the rear shifter .
be cautious with the rear shifter .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the wheel out. Pull the rear shifter into a straight line so the wheel will be able to slide out smoothly. Pull out the wheel with one hand while you hold the rear shifter. Be cautious with the rear shifter.

Lines.Text: now that the rear wheel is off the bike , use the tire lever to get under the tire .
once the tire lever is under the tire , bring it around the rim of the wheel slowly sliding the tire off wheel .
ideally , three tire levers are used to get the tire off . however , one tire lever has proven to be sufficient .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the rear wheel is off the bike, use the tire lever to get under the tire. Once the tire lever is under the tire, bring it around the rim of the wheel slowly sliding the tire off wheel. Ideally, three tire levers are used to get the tire off. However, one tire lever has proven to be sufficient.
Tools_extracted: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Lines.Text: pull out the inner tube .
the valve should be the last thing that is pulled out from the wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the inner tube. The valve should be the last thing that is pulled out from the wheel.

Lines.Text: replace inner tube or patch the hole if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace inner tube or patch the hole if necessary.

Lines.Text: place the inner tube back inside the tire .
put the valve into the hole first , then bring the inner tube around the rim of the wheel .
using the tire lever , pry the tire back onto the wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the inner tube back inside the tire. Put the valve into the hole first, then bring the inner tube around the rim of the wheel. Using the tire lever, pry the tire back onto the wheel.
Tools_extracted: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Lines.Text: now that the tire is back on the wheel , screw the adapter onto the co2 cartridge and place it on the valve .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the tire is back on the wheel, screw the adapter onto the CO2 cartridge and place it on the valve.

Lines.Text: press the co2 cartridge towards the rim of the wheel .
the inner tube inflates quickly , so hold the co2 cartridge for a short period of time .
the valve might freeze while doing this , but this is normal

Steps.Text_raw: Press the CO2 cartridge towards the rim of the wheel. The inner tube inflates quickly, so hold the CO2 cartridge for a short period of time. The valve might freeze while doing this, but this is normal

Lines.Text: fit the wheel back onto the bike .
pull the rear shifter into a straight line and place the gears underneath the chain to slide into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Fit the wheel back onto the bike. Pull the rear shifter into a straight line and place the gears underneath the chain to slide into place.

Lines.Text: tighten the quick-release lever and close it .
twist the lever as you hold the cap on the opposite side as tight as possible .
re-engage the brakes .
turn the grey lever downwards on the brake , such as in step 2.

Steps.Text_raw: Tighten the quick-release lever and close it. Twist the lever as you hold the cap on the opposite side as tight as possible. Re-engage the brakes. Turn the grey lever downwards on the brake, such as in step 2.
Tools_extracted: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Lines.Text: pedal a little while the bike is lifted slightly off the ground to move the chain back into place .
the chain was placed on a different chain ring when the rear tire was pulled out , so it needs to readjust .

Steps.Text_raw: Pedal a little while the bike is lifted slightly off the ground to move the chain back into place. The chain was placed on a different  chain ring when the rear tire was pulled out, so it needs to readjust.
Tools_extracted: park tool tl-1 tire lever set

Title: How to Replace a Bottom Bracket on a Bicycle

Lines.Text: flip the bike so that it is resting on the handle bars and seat .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the bike so that it is resting on the handle bars and seat.

Lines.Text: take out the bolts on the base of the crank using an allen wrench that fits the bolt .
do this to both sides . set the bolts aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the bolts on the base of the crank using an allen wrench that fits the bolt. Do this to both sides. Set the bolts aside.

Lines.Text: screw the crank puller into the place where the bolts used to be .
tighten the crank puller until it pulls the crank off the bike .
repeat for the other side .
set aside the cranks , keeping track of which side each one goes on .

Steps.Text_raw: Screw the crank puller into the place where the bolts used to be. Tighten the crank puller until it pulls the crank off the bike. Repeat for the other side. Set aside the cranks, keeping track of which side each one goes on.

Lines.Text: ''go to the side that does not have the drive train . '' this side must be completed first !
insert the bottom bracket tool into the bottom bracket . use the tool to turn the bottom bracket '''counter clock wise''' . it will be difficult to turn , but enough force will get it to turn .
completely remove the small side of the bottom bracket .
repeat for the side with the drive train , except turn the bottom bracket tool '''clockwise''' this time .

Steps.Text_raw: ''Go to the side that does not have the drive train.'' This side must be completed first! Insert the bottom bracket tool into the bottom bracket. Use the tool to turn the bottom bracket '''counter clock wise'''. It will be difficult to turn, but enough force will get it to turn. Completely remove the small side of the bottom bracket. Repeat for the side with the drive train, except turn the bottom bracket tool '''clockwise''' this time.

Lines.Text: pull out the damaged bottom bracket from the drive train side .
discard the broken bottom bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the damaged bottom bracket from the drive train side. Discard the broken bottom bracket.

Lines.Text: get the new bottom bracket .
notice the left ( l ) and right ( r ) markers on the part . this will help guide you when inserting the part .
grease both parts of the threads using the paint brush . apply enough grease so that the threads are evenly coated .

Steps.Text_raw: Get the new bottom bracket. Notice the left (L) and right (R) markers on the part. This will help guide you when inserting the part. Grease both parts of the threads using the paint brush. Apply enough grease so that the threads are evenly coated.

Lines.Text: insert the bottom bracket from the drive side of the bike with the larger side facing your hand .
gently screw in the second set of threads on the other side with your fingers .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the bottom bracket from the drive side of the bike with the larger side facing your hand. Gently screw in the second set of threads on  the other side with your fingers.

Lines.Text: use the bottom bracket tool to screw in the larger side ( drive side ) of the bottom bracket . make sure to screw it in''' counter clock wise . '''
screw the bottom bracket in all the way , but make sure not to tighten it down .
repeat for the smaller side , except screw the bottom bracket in '''clock wise''' .
tighten both sides down with the bottom bracket tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the bottom bracket tool to screw in the larger side (drive side) of the bottom bracket. Make sure to screw it in''' counter clock wise.''' Screw the bottom bracket in all the way, but make sure not to tighten it down. Repeat for the smaller side, except screw the bottom bracket in '''clock wise'''. Tighten both sides down with the bottom bracket tool.

Lines.Text: put the cranks back on their corresponding sides .
make sure ''the chain goes back around the chain ring'' .
put the bolts back through and tighten them into place with the allen wrench used earlier .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the cranks back on their corresponding sides. Make sure ''the chain goes back around the chain ring''. Put the bolts back through and tighten them into place with the allen wrench used earlier.

Lines.Text: rotate the pedals with your hands to check that the bottom bracket is rotating smoothly and not catching .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the pedals with your hands to check that the bottom bracket is rotating smoothly and not catching.

Subject: Bottom Bracket

Title: How to Replace the Front Brake Pads on a 1994 Honda VFR 750

Lines.Text: place the motorcycle on its center stand to keep the bike upright and stable . if your motorcycle doesnt have an attached center stand , use a wheel chock or a race stand ( front or rear ) . the kickstand is usable , but will reduce accessibility to the left caliper .
before beginning this fix , make sure the brake rotors and calipers have time to cool if the bike was recently used .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the motorcycle on its center stand to keep the bike upright and stable. If your motorcycle doesn’t have an attached center stand, use a wheel chock or a race stand (front or rear). The kickstand is usable, but will reduce accessibility to the left caliper. Before beginning this fix, make sure the brake rotors and calipers have time to cool if the bike was recently used.

Lines.Text: the caliper is attached to the forks by two 12-mm hex bolts . remove these bolts with a 12 mm wrench .
set these bolts aside for when you re-attach the caliper at the of the guide .

Steps.Text_raw: The caliper is attached to the forks by two 12-mm hex bolts. Remove these bolts with a 12mm wrench. Set these bolts aside for when you re-attach the caliper at the of the guide.

Lines.Text: to remove the brake pads , use your flathead screwdriver to remove the cover for the brake pad retainer pin .
after the cover is removed , use the 5 mm allen wrench to remove the retainer pin . do not remove the pin yet , just make sure it is no longer threaded in the caliper .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the brake pads, use your flathead screwdriver to remove the cover for the brake pad retainer pin. After the cover is removed, use the 5mm allen wrench to remove the retainer pin. Do not remove the pin yet, just make sure it is no longer threaded in the caliper.

Lines.Text: with a 12 mm wrench , unthread the nut that attaches the bracket to the caliper .
once the nut is fully unthreaded the bracket will slide and rotate upward , exposing the brake pads .
remove the retainer pin , and the brake pads will fall out .

Steps.Text_raw: With a 12mm wrench, unthread the nut that attaches the bracket to the caliper. Once the nut is fully unthreaded the bracket will slide and rotate upward, exposing the brake pads. Remove the retainer pin, and the brake pads will fall out.

Lines.Text: since the caliper is disassembled it is a good idea to clean it . brake cleaner is a good product , but i prefer to use hot , soapy water instead .
use an old toothbrush to scrub the caliper , focusing on the pistons . try to remove as much of the brake dust as possible .
brake dust is hazardous to your health . do not inhale any of the dust particles , and try to sustain minimal skin contact if possible .

Steps.Text_raw: Since the caliper is disassembled it is a good idea to clean it. Brake cleaner is a good product, but I prefer to use hot, soapy water instead. Use an old toothbrush to scrub the caliper, focusing on the pistons. Try to remove as much of the brake dust as possible. Brake dust is hazardous to your health. Do not inhale any of the dust particles, and try to sustain minimal skin contact if possible.

Lines.Text: inspect your new brake pads for any damage .
if you have anti squeal brake gel , you can apply some to the back ( non-friction side ) of the brake pads . this is not necessary , but could possibly prevent squeaky brakes in the future .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect your new brake pads for any damage. If you have anti squeal brake gel, you can apply some to the back (non-friction side) of the brake pads. This is not necessary, but could possibly prevent squeaky brakes in the future.

Lines.Text: in order to allow the brake pads to leave a gap large enough for the rotor during re-installation , the pistons must be pushed back into the caliper .
the pistons only need to be pushed in about 5 mm . generally the pistons can be pushed in by hand , but if not , a c-clamp can be used .
if a c-clamp is not available , you can put a screwdriver in between the brake pads and carefully pry them apart to force the pistons in .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to allow the brake pads to leave a gap large enough for the rotor during re-installation, the pistons must be pushed back into the caliper. The pistons only need to be pushed in about 5mm. Generally the pistons can be pushed in by hand, but if not, a c-clamp can be used. If a c-clamp is not available, you can put a screwdriver in between the brake pads and carefully pry them apart to force the pistons in.

Lines.Text: with the bracket extended upwards , hook the end of the brake pad on the retainer clip so the friction pad faces inward , and the hole on the opposite side lines up with the hole for the retainer pin .
rotate the bracket down . this will cause the retainer clip to clamp down on the edge of the pads .
thread the bracket nut back into the bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: With the bracket extended upwards, hook the end of the brake pad on the retainer clip so the friction pad faces inward, and the hole on the opposite side lines up with the hole for the retainer pin. Rotate the bracket down. This will cause the retainer clip to clamp down on the edge of the pads. Thread the bracket nut back into the bracket.

Lines.Text: if you havent cleaned the retainer pin with soap and water , now is a good time . if any corrosion is present on the smooth part of the pin , use steel wool to smooth it out . if you have brake grease available , you can apply a thin coat to the smooth part of the pin .
make sure the pin goes through the holes on the brake pads , and thread the pin into the housing .
tighten down the retainer pin to 11-14 ft-lbs ( 15-20 nm ) with the torque wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: If you haven’t cleaned the retainer pin with soap and water, now is a good time. If any corrosion is present on the smooth part of the pin, use steel wool to smooth it out. If you have brake grease available, you can apply a thin coat to the smooth part of the pin. Make sure the pin goes through the holes on the brake pads, and thread the pin into the housing. Tighten down the retainer pin to 11-14 ft-lbs (15-20 N*m) with the torque wrench.

Lines.Text: place the caliper so that the brake rotor fits in between the pads .

line up the bracket with the mount on the forks , and using the two 12 mm bolts you set aside previously , attach the bracket to the mount . using a torque wrench , torque the bolts to 17-22 ft-lbs ( 24-30 nm )
if you haven't done so already , re-attach the retainer pin cap with a flathead screwdriver .
since the vfr 750 has two rotors in the front , repeat these steps on the opposite side to replace the brake pads on the other caliper .
before riding the motorcycle , be sure to pump the front brake until the lever becomes firm . pressure must be restored to the system before it can be safely used .
once the fix is completed , be sure to follow the proper brake pad bedding instructions to maximize braking performance .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the caliper so that the brake rotor fits in between the pads. Line up the bracket with the mount on the forks, and using the two 12mm bolts you set aside previously, attach the bracket to the mount. Using a torque wrench, torque the bolts to 17-22 ft-lbs (24-30 N*m) If you haven't done so already, re-attach the retainer pin cap with a flathead screwdriver. Since the VFR 750 has two rotors in the front, repeat these steps on the opposite side to replace the brake pads on the other caliper. Before riding the motorcycle, be sure to pump the front brake until the lever becomes firm. Pressure must be restored to the system before it can be safely used. Once the fix is completed, be sure to follow the proper brake pad bedding instructions to maximize braking performance.

Subject: Front Brake Pads

Title: How to refurbish and clean longboard bushings

Lines.Text: start by placing your board on its top so that you can access the trucks .
use an adjustable wrench to remove the large nut that is screwed onto the end of the kingpin .

Steps.Text_raw: Start by placing your board on its top so that you can access the trucks. Use an adjustable wrench to remove the large nut that is screwed onto the end of the kingpin.

Lines.Text: take apart the trucks by removing the parts in this order : washer 1 , bushing 1 , metal hangar , bushing 2 , washer 2
to remove the hanger , wiggle it off of the kingpin ( large bolt ) , then lift it out of the pivot cup .
make sure you remember the order of the parts ! take a picture if you need to , or simply refer to the other side of the board for the correct truck setup .

Steps.Text_raw: Take apart the trucks by removing the parts in this order: washer #1, bushing #1, metal hangar, bushing #2, washer #2 To remove the hanger, wiggle it off of the kingpin (large bolt), then lift it out of the pivot cup. Make sure you remember the order of the parts! Take a picture if you need to, or simply refer to the other side of the board for the correct truck setup.

Lines.Text: using pliers ( needle nose would work best ) , take out the small pivot cup where the metal hangar was resting .
place all of the pieces aside . make sure to not lose any , as one missing piece means your board can't be put back together .

Steps.Text_raw: Using pliers (needle nose would work best), take out the small pivot cup where the metal hangar was resting. Place all of the pieces aside. Make sure to not lose any, as one missing piece means your board can't be put back together.

Lines.Text: apply a small amount of rubbing alcohol on a cloth or sheet of paper towel . clean the pivot cup and bushings .
rinse the pivot cup and bushings by running the items through hot water .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply a small amount of rubbing alcohol on a cloth or sheet of paper towel. Clean the pivot cup and bushings. Rinse the pivot cup and bushings by running the items through hot water.

Lines.Text: take a small pot and bring a moderate amount of water to a rolling boil .
place the bushings in the boiling water and cover the pot . boil the bushings for 10-15 minutes .
boiling water is hot ! make sure to be careful when putting in the bushings .

Steps.Text_raw: Take a small pot and bring a moderate amount of water to a rolling boil. Place the bushings in the boiling water and cover the pot. Boil the bushings for 10-15 minutes. Boiling water is hot! Make sure to be careful when putting in the bushings.

Lines.Text: using the pliers , take the bushings out of the pot .
if you are not comfortable with the softness just yet , boil the bushings for 5 more minutes .
let the bushings cool for 2 minutes .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the pliers, take the bushings out of the pot. If you are not comfortable with the softness just yet, boil the bushings for 5 more minutes. Let the bushings cool for 2 minutes.

Lines.Text: take the edge of a soap bar and rub the bottom and top of the bushings until a film of soap is visible .
using a knife , cut small soap shavings and place a small amount in the pivot cup .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the edge of a soap bar and rub the bottom and top of the bushings until a film of soap is visible. Using a knife, cut small soap shavings and place a small amount in the pivot cup.

Lines.Text: reassemble the trucks by first placing the pivot cup back in its hole
place the washers , bushings , and hanger on the large bolt , and then tighten the nut last .

Steps.Text_raw: Reassemble the trucks by first placing the pivot cup back in its hole Place the washers, bushings, and hanger on the large bolt, and then tighten the nut last.

Lines.Text: once the trucks have been reassembled , step on the board and test the turning sensitivity .
if turning is hard or requires you to lean too much , loosen the nut .
if turning is too loose and not stable , tighten the nut .
you have successfully tuned your longboard with your new bushings and it's ready to ride !

Steps.Text_raw: Once the trucks have been reassembled, step on the board and test the turning sensitivity. If turning is hard or requires you to lean too much, loosen the nut. If turning is too loose and not stable, tighten the nut. You have successfully tuned your longboard with your "new" bushings and it's ready to ride!

Lines.Text: use a phillips/flat head screwdriver , along with a skate tool or set of pliers , to loosen the nuts which fasten the trucks to the deck .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips/flat head screw driver, along with a skate tool or set of pliers, to loosen the nuts which fasten the trucks to the deck.

Lines.Text: use your fingers to fully loosen and remove the nuts from the bolts .
nuts are small and easy to lose track of .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers to fully loosen and remove the nuts from the bolts. Nuts are small and easy to lose track of.

Lines.Text: use your hands to remove the trucks from the deck .
make sure the kingpin is facing outward , if the kingpin is not properly reinstalled , the trucks will fail to perform properly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your hands to remove the trucks from the deck. Make sure the kingpin is facing outward, If the kingpin is not properly reinstalled, the trucks will fail to perform properly.

Lines.Text: remove the truck raiser if applicable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the truck raiser if applicable.

Lines.Text: remove the bolts from the factory drilled holes on the deck .
note that the bolts are small and easy to lose track of .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bolts from the factory drilled holes on the deck. Note that the bolts are small and easy to lose track of.

Lines.Text: clean the deck with a moist cloth or cleaning solution .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the deck with a moist cloth or cleaning solution.

Lines.Text: clean the trucks with a moist cloth or cleaning solution .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the trucks with a moist cloth or cleaning solution.

Lines.Text: clean the hardware by either soaking it in cleaning solution , or by manually cleaning it with a moist cloth .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the hardware by either soaking it in cleaning solution, or by manually cleaning it with a moist cloth.

Lines.Text: repeat steps 1-7 with the second truck .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat steps 1-7 with the second truck.

Lines.Text: after re-installation , check and confirm that all the bolts and nuts are tight . the bolts should be slightly submerged in the wood of the deck
over tightening the bolts can cause them to strip .
failure to tighten the bolts and nuts properly may lead to improper performance .

Steps.Text_raw: After re-installation, check and confirm that all the bolts and nuts are tight. The bolts should be slightly submerged in the wood of the deck Over tightening the bolts can cause them to strip. Failure to tighten the bolts and nuts properly may lead to improper performance.

Lines.Text: after re-installing the trucks , check and confirm the kingpin is facing outward .
failure to do this will cause the longboard's functions to be inverted , which may lead to personal injury .

Steps.Text_raw: After re-installing the trucks, check and confirm the kingpin is facing outward. Failure to do this will cause the longboard's functions to be inverted, which may lead to personal injury.

Lines.Text: disconnect the dc power banana plugs from any power source .
when not powered , the chargers screen will be blank .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the DC power banana plugs from any power source. When not powered, the chargers screen will be blank.

Lines.Text: press down on the tab located on the top of the white molex connector and firmly pull away from the charger body .

Steps.Text_raw: Press down on the tab located on the top of the white molex connector and firmly pull away from the charger body.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws located on the right side cover of the charger .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws located on the right side cover of the charger.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws located on the right side panel .
do not pull on the panel , the dc power cables are rigidly attached to the panel by the black plastic grommet , this grommet is removed in the next step .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws located on the right side panel. Do not pull on the panel, the DC power cables are rigidly attached to the panel by the black plastic grommet, this grommet is removed in the next step.

Lines.Text: locate the smaller , secondary part of the grommet .
using needle nose pliers , gently sqeeze on the secondary part of the grommet and the opposite side of the grommet while pushing the grommet through the hole towards the exterior side of the panel .
once pushed through the hole , the grommet can be removed from the wires and set aside .
the smaller , secondary part of the grommet is connected to the main part of the grommet by a thin piece of plastic , ensure this piece is not severed during this process .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the smaller, secondary part of the grommet. Using needle nose pliers, gently sqeeze on the secondary part of the grommet and the opposite side of the grommet while pushing the grommet through the hole towards the exterior side of the panel. Once pushed through the hole, the grommet can be removed from the wires and set aside. The smaller, secondary part of the grommet is connected to the main part of the grommet by a thin piece of plastic, ensure this piece is not severed during this process.

Lines.Text: one by one , pass both banana connectors through the hole in the left side panel .

Steps.Text_raw: One by one, pass both banana connectors through the hole in the left side panel.

Lines.Text: remove the two screws located on the front side of the charger .
remove the two screws located on the back side of the charger , above the fan screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws located on the front side of the charger. Remove the two screws located on the back side of the charger, above the fan screws.

Lines.Text: desolder the two wires connected to the female banana plug ports for both channel 1 and 2 ( left and ride sides of the charger ) .
too high temperature setting will cause the plastic banana plug port covers to melt , use only as much heat as needed to flow the solder .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the two wires connected to the female banana plug ports for both channel 1 and 2 (left and ride sides of the charger). Too high temperature setting will cause the plastic banana plug port covers to melt, use only as much heat as needed to flow the solder.

Lines.Text: the top cover is still connected by three ribbon cables to the mainboard . gently lift the top cover until you can slide your fingers or a spudger into the charger to disconnect the three molex connectors .
lcd segment display connector
backlight power connector
front panel buttons ribbon

Steps.Text_raw: The top cover is still connected by three ribbon cables to the mainboard. Gently lift the top cover until you can slide your fingers or a spudger into the charger to disconnect the three molex connectors. LCD Segment Display Connector Backlight Power Connector Front Panel Buttons Ribbon

Lines.Text: use a spudger or shim to gently separate the top plastic bar from the large lower piece . once separated , the ribon cable can be slipped out of the housing .
disconnect the two white molex connectors from the board mount plugs .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a spudger or shim to gently separate the top plastic bar from the large lower piece. Once separated, the ribon cable can be slipped out of the housing. Disconnect the two white molex connectors from the board mount plugs.

Lines.Text: the top faceplate can now be separated from the lower charger assembly .
be sure to separate the two parts slowly , checking for snagged wires and other hazards that could cause damage to the charger .
inside you'll find :
pic24 hj128 gp310 16-bit microcontroller
pic icsp programming pins ( 6 pins )
ka324 ad quad operational amplifiers ( 4 total )
24 lc32 a 32 k i2 c serial eeprom

Steps.Text_raw: The top faceplate can now be separated from the lower charger assembly. Be sure to separate the two parts slowly, checking for snagged wires and other hazards that could cause damage to the charger. Title: 5 LED 6 Mode Rear Bike Light  LED Replacement

Lines.Text: obtain the necessary tools

Steps.Text_raw: Obtain the necessary tools

Lines.Text: insert coin or any flat object into edge of light cover
pry open until cover loosens

Steps.Text_raw: Insert coin or any flat object into edge of light cover Pry open until cover loosens

Lines.Text: remove the single phillips 00 screw holding the circuit board in place
remove both aaa batteries

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the single Phillips #00 screw holding the circuit board in place Remove both AAA batteries

Lines.Text: remove both phillips 00 screws holding the clip in place
remove the clip with a flat object
the button will fall out when removing the clip . do not lose it !

Steps.Text_raw: Remove both Phillips #00 screws holding the clip in place Remove the clip with a flat object The button will fall out when removing the clip. Do not lose it!

Lines.Text: congratulations ! you completed your device teardown !

Steps.Text_raw: Congratulations! You completed your device teardown!

Lines.Text: warm up the soldering iron
tin the tip of the soldering iron
apply a small amount of solder to the tip
wipe on a damp sponge
touch the tip of the soldering iron to the led solder to liquify it
apply solder wick to absorb solder
this guide uses a desoldering pump instead of desoldering wick . the wick would work better .

Steps.Text_raw: Warm up the soldering iron Tin the tip of the soldering iron Apply a small amount of solder to the tip Wipe on a damp sponge Touch the tip of the soldering iron to the led solder to liquify it Apply solder wick to absorb solder This guide uses a desoldering pump  instead of desoldering wick. The wick would work better.

Lines.Text: once you remove enough solder , remove the led

Steps.Text_raw: Once you remove enough solder,  remove the LED

Lines.Text: place the new led through the open holes
the led should cover the schematic symbol on the circuit board and the flat edge of the led should line up with the tip of the diode symbol shown by the arrow
if the led does not stay , you can tape it in place on the opposite side of the board
warm up the trace on the circuit board and the led lead with the soldering iron
wipe your soldering iron on the damp sponge every time you pick it up
apply solder to the lead until the hole completely fills with solder

Steps.Text_raw: Place the new LED through the open holes The LED should cover the schematic symbol on the circuit board and the flat edge of the LED should line up with the tip of the diode symbol shown by the arrow If the LED does not stay, you can tape it in place on the opposite side of the board Warm up the trace on the circuit board and the LED lead with the soldering iron Wipe your soldering iron on the damp sponge every time you pick it up Apply solder to the lead until the hole completely fills with solder

Lines.Text: reassemble by following the teardown in reverse order
you now have a customized bike light or a working led !
we replaced the middle led with blue and the two outside leds with white . we set the bike light on the last mode . enjoy !
certain colors of leds may be illegal as rear bike lights . use at your own risk or for a different application !

Steps.Text_raw: Reassemble by following the teardown in reverse order You now have a customized bike light or a working LED! We replaced the middle LED with blue and the two outside LEDs with white. We set the bike light on the last mode. Enjoy! Certain colors of LEDs may be illegal as rear bike lights. Use at your own risk or for a different application!

Title: TYLT VU Wireless charging car mount Disassembly

Lines.Text: first thing you want to do is lift up the corners of the rubber mat that makes up the center that your phone sits on . here you will find 4 screws ( one in each corner ) . remove these screws and the whole front panel should come off .

Steps.Text_raw: First thing you want to do is lift up the corners of the rubber mat that makes up the center that your phone sits on. Here you will find 4 screws (One in each corner). Remove these screws and the whole front panel should come off.

Lines.Text: next you need to be careful not to brake any of the 3 wires running from the main charging circuit to the power intake port , that sits on a seperate chip in the bottom housing . this is held on by 1 screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Next you need to be careful not to brake any of the 3 wires running from the main charging circuit to the power intake port, that sits on a seperate chip in the bottom housing. This is held on by 1 screw.

Lines.Text: now your should be left with this bottom part . to get to the sprockets and the locking mechanism inside , you need to remove the plate that is secured with 4 screws + 1 smaller screw . when that plate is removed ( might take some slight convincing ) you will see the sprockets and mechanism seen in picture 2 and 3.

Steps.Text_raw: Now your should be left with this bottom part. To get to the sprockets and the locking mechanism inside, you need to remove the plate that is secured with 4 screws + 1 smaller screw. When that plate is removed (might take some slight convincing) you will see the sprockets and mechanism seen in picture 2 and 3.

Lines.Text: mind the small spring in picture 1 when assembling , this pulls both the clamps out when the button is pushed . also remember to realign all the parts when assembling . other than that it is the reverse of dissasembling .

Steps.Text_raw: Mind the small spring in picture 1 when assembling, this pulls both the clamps out when the button is pushed. Also remember to realign all the parts when assembling. Other than that it is the reverse of dissasembling.

Lines.Text: push the chain tensioner towards the front of the bicycle to release the tension on the chain .
unroute the chain from the chainrings .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the chain tensioner towards the front of the bicycle to release the tension on the chain. Unroute the chain from the chainrings.

Lines.Text: remove the 8 mm hex screw from the crank arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 8 mm Hex screw from the crank arm.

Lines.Text: remove the crank arm and chainrings by pulling the crank arm away from the bicycle frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the crank arm and chainrings by pulling the crank arm away from the bicycle frame.

Lines.Text: remove the four 5 mm hex screws that mount the crank arm to the chainrings .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 5 mm Hex screws that mount the crank arm to the chainrings.

Lines.Text: rotate the largest chainring 45 degrees in either direction .
remove the crank arm from the chainrings .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the largest chainring 45 degrees in either direction. Remove the crank arm from the chainrings.

Lines.Text: using 000 screwdriver remove the 5 mm screw retaining the propeller to the rotating post ; there is one for each propeller .
you can now safely pull the propeller away from its apparatus .

Steps.Text_raw: Using #PH000 screwdriver remove the 5mm screw retaining the propeller to the rotating post; there is one for each propeller. You can now safely pull the propeller away from its apparatus.

Lines.Text: after removing the propellers , unscrew all 4 ( 3x3 mm ) screws connecting the electronics to the frame .
once you removed all the screws holding the plastic dust cover to the frame , pull the 2 led bars through the dust cover and remove the thin plastic dust cover from the drone .
you can now access the piece connecting the electronics to the drone cover , but do not remove electronics until after disconnecting the drone head lamp first .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the propellers, unscrew all 4 (3x3mm) screws connecting the electronics to the frame. Once you removed all the screws holding the plastic dust cover to the frame, pull the 2 LED bars through the dust cover and remove the thin plastic dust cover from the drone. You can now access the piece connecting the electronics to the drone cover, but do not remove electronics until after disconnecting the drone head lamp first.

Lines.Text: step two is disconnecting and removing the head lamp .
use a screwdriver for 5 mm screw to remove head lamp of drone .
you can now disconnect the electronics from the frame of the drone by pulling each arm out of the hole in the frame holding it in place .
do not try to separate the frame from the electronics yet ! first , check to see if there is tape holding the head lamp wires in place underneath the electronics .

Steps.Text_raw: Step two is disconnecting and removing the head lamp. Use a screw driver for 5mm screw to remove head lamp of drone. You can now disconnect the electronics from the frame of the drone by pulling each arm out of the hole in the frame holding it in place. Do not try to separate the frame from the electronics yet! First, check to see if there is tape holding the head lamp wires in place underneath the electronics.

Lines.Text: lastly , if there is white tape over the black and red wires for the head lamp , remove the tape with a metal spudger .
remove this tape but try to keep it in reusable condition to re-secure the headlight later so there are no loose wires .
separate the plastic tabs securing the motor arms to the drone cover and delicately pull out the arm . do this for all 4 arms to remove the frame from the cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Lastly, if there is white tape over the black and red wires for the head lamp, remove the tape with a metal spudger. Remove this tape but try to keep it in reusable condition to re-secure the headlight later so there are no loose wires. Separate the plastic tabs securing the motor arms to the drone cover and delicately pull out the arm. Do this for all 4 arms to remove the frame from the cover.

Lines.Text: using a 000 screwdriver to remove the 4 ( 5 mm ) corner screws that secure both the receiving board and the motor arm .
notice how the wires tuck neatly in the bottom channel of the motor arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a #PH000  screwdriver to remove the 4 (5mm) corner screws that secure both the receiving board and the motor arm. Notice how  the wires tuck neatly in the bottom channel of the motor arm.

Lines.Text: carefully slide the arm out from the socket .
a metal spudger , plastic removal tool or tweezers work best to remove the connectors from the receiving board .
the cables connecting to the receiving board will be secured with a light adhesive that can be easily scraped away to remove the desired connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully slide the arm out from the socket. A metal spudger, plastic removal tool or  tweezers work best to remove the connectors from the receiving board. The cables connecting to the receiving board will be secured with a light adhesive that can be easily scraped away to remove the desired connector.

Lines.Text: motor direction and propeller direction is crucial to proper flight , refer to this format .
the ++front left++ motor identified by red/blue wires is a '''standard''' ( ''clockwise'' ) spinning motor , it pairs with a ''white'' '''a2 ''' propeller .
the ++front right++ motor identified by the black/white wires is a '''reverse''' ( ''counterclockwise'' ) spinning motor , it pairs with a ''white'' '''b2 '''propeller .
the ++back left++ motor identified by the black/white wires is a '''reverse''' ( ''counterclockwise'' ) spinning motor , it pairs with a ''black'' '''b1 ''' propeller .
the ++back right++ motor identified by the red/blue wires is a '''standard''' ( ''clockwise'' ) spinning motor , it pairs with a ''black'' '''a1 ''' propeller .

Steps.Text_raw: Motor direction and propeller direction is crucial to proper flight, refer to this format. The ++Front Left++ motor identified by Red/Blue wires is a '''Standard'''(''Clockwise'') spinning motor, it pairs with a ''White'' '''A2''' propeller. The ++Front Right++ motor identified by the Black/White wires is a '''Reverse'''(''CounterClockwise'') spinning motor, it pairs with a  ''White'' '''B2 '''propeller. The ++Back Left++ motor identified by the Black/White wires is a '''Reverse'''(''CounterClockwise'') spinning motor, it pairs with a ''Black'' '''B1''' propeller. The ++Back Right++ motor identified by the Red/Blue wires is a '''Standard'''(''Clockwise'') spinning motor, it pairs with a ''Black'' '''A1''' propeller.

Lines.Text: the wiring can appear confusing , don't be alarmed . it's quite easy , and absolutely necessary for proper flight .
the 4 bottom connectors receive the motor power cables that are red/yellow wire pairs from each motor . counting the sockets 1-4 from left to right .
front right motor connects to socket 1.
front left motor connects to socket 2.
rear left motor connects to socket 3.
rear right motor connects to socket 4.
the red/green wire pairs from each motor power the led to that branch , they connect to 4 of 6 sockets on the top of the receiving board . there is no sequence required .

the headlight led , and underside led bars connect to the remaining 2 sockets on the top of the receiving board . again , no sequence is required . all led red/black and red/green wire pairs connect to top of the receiving board .

Steps.Text_raw: The wiring can appear confusing, don't be alarmed. It's quite easy, and absolutely necessary for proper flight. The 4 bottom connectors receive the motor power cables that are Red/Yellow wire pairs from each motor. Counting the sockets 1-4 from left to right. Front Right motor connects to socket 1. Front Left motor connects to socket 2. Rear Left motor connects to socket 3. Rear Right motor connects to socket 4. The Red/Green wire pairs from each motor power the LED to that branch, they connect to 4 of 6 sockets on the top of the receiving board. There is no sequence required. The headlight LED, and underside LED bars connect to the remaining 2 sockets on the top of the receiving board. Again, no sequence is required.  All LED Red/Black and Red/Green wire pairs connect to top of the receiving board.

Lines.Text: if the tooth gear attached to your carbon tube is the only gear damaged/stripped , then you need not continue .
