Steps.Text_raw: Last step is to take out all 4 (5mm) screws from the main frame where camera is fixed using a PH #000 screwdriver. After all four screws are removed from each corner of the camera apparatus, separate it from the main frame.

Title: DJI Phantom 2 Vision Plus Gimbal Yaw Arm Replacement

Lines.Text: first step is to remove the battery , props and turn the phantom upside down .
the first thing to remove are the retaining clips from the gimbal mount .
i tried saving them at first but soon realized i would rather replace them to ensure the gimbal doesn't fall off in mid flight .
there was a small bag of parts included with the phantom when it was purchased . it included two more retaining clips .

Steps.Text_raw: First step is to remove the battery, props and turn the Phantom upside down. The first thing  to remove are the retaining clips from the gimbal mount. I tried saving them at first but soon realized I would rather replace them to ensure the gimbal doesn't fall off in mid flight. There was a small bag of parts included with the Phantom when it was purchased. It included two more retaining clips.

Lines.Text: there are four tabs on the retaining clip . i simply took my wire cutters and removed one of those tabs .
the clip was easy to remove . save these clips , they will come in handy later .

Steps.Text_raw: There are four tabs on the retaining clip. I simply took my wire cutters and removed one of those tabs. The clip was easy to remove. Save these clips, they will come in handy later.

Lines.Text: simply lift the gimbal out of the rubber mounts and fold back towards the front end of the phantom .
use a small tool to press the clip holding in the smallest connector .
i used the same tool to work the other two connectors up out of the gimbal . i had to work them from side to side a little to free them .

Steps.Text_raw: Simply lift the gimbal out of the rubber mounts and fold back towards the front end of the Phantom. Use a small tool to press the clip holding in the smallest connector. I used the same tool to work the other two connectors up out of the gimbal. I had to work them from side to side a little to free them.

Lines.Text: the gimbal and camera are now free and easy to work on .
loosen this hex screw . i'm sure ifixit has a tool that will fit this perfectly .
remove the four phillips screws on the bottom plates . there are two plates here with two screws each . be careful you don't lose the button on the bottom of the gimbal .

Steps.Text_raw: The gimbal and camera are now free and easy to work on. Loosen this hex screw. I'm sure iFixit has a tool that will fit this perfectly. Remove the four Philips screws on the bottom plates. There are two plates here with two screws each. Be careful you don't lose the button on the bottom of the gimbal.

Lines.Text: here you see the smaller plate outlined in red . these aren't that tricky to reassemble . you just have to keep the button in place .
in the second picture you can see how i held the button for reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Here you see the smaller plate outlined in red. These aren't that tricky to reassemble. You just have to keep the button in place. In the second picture you can see how I held the button for reassembly.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the covers off the gimbal . there is a bearing here that can fall out , be careful not to lose it .
as you lift the parts be very gentle as there is a ribbon cable attaching the camera to the main circuit board . the metal plates lift out of the way and the gimbal is now in two pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the covers off the gimbal. There is a bearing here that can fall out, be careful not to lose it. As you lift the parts be very gentle as there is a ribbon cable attaching the camera to the main circuit board. The metal plates lift out of the way and the gimbal is now in two pieces.

Lines.Text: the ribbon is held in by a zif slot .
watch the small components soldered below the tab .
use a plastic tool or your fingernail to flip the tab up .
once the tab is up you can simply pull out the ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: The ribbon is held in by a zif slot. Watch the small components soldered below the tab. Use a plastic tool or your fingernail to flip the tab up. Once the tab is up you can simply pull out the ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: you must remove these three screws . one is smaller than the other two .
next you need to lift the small circuit board up gently out of the yaw arm .

Steps.Text_raw: You must remove these three screws. One is smaller than the other two. Next you need to lift the small circuit board up gently out of the yaw arm.

Lines.Text: next you need to peel the ribbon cable off of the yaw arm . it is sticky , but not too bad . i would recommend using a hair dryer to warm it if possible to soften the adhesive .
carefully peel it off the yaw arm .
remove the brown ribbon cable from the circuit board first . this is another zif slot with a tab the needs to be lifted with your fingernail .
after the brown cable is removed it is easier to remove the black ribbon cable .
set the circuit board aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Next you need to peel the ribbon cable off of the yaw arm. It is sticky, but not too bad. I would recommend using a hair dryer to warm it if possible to soften the adhesive. Carefully peel it off the yaw arm. Remove the brown ribbon cable from the circuit board first. This is another zif slot with a tab the needs to be lifted with your fingernail. after the brown cable is removed it is easier to remove the black ribbon cable. Set the circuit board aside.

Lines.Text: once the circuit board is out you can remove the three screws inside .
carefully remove the yaw arm , watching that you don't damage the ribbon cable .
you are done , time to install the new yaw arm !

Steps.Text_raw: Once the circuit board is out you can remove the three screws inside. Carefully remove the yaw arm, watching that you don't damage the ribbon cable. You are done, time to install the new yaw arm!

Lines.Text: i found it easier to reinstall the brown ribbon cable before the black one .
remember to tape the button in place when reassembling .

i used these clips when i reattached the gimbal to test everything , before flying . if i had to go through and redo the ribbon cable connections it would have been easy to remove the gimbal with these in place .
be sure to use new retaining clips before flying ! ! !
my camera still wasn't level . i had to use the camera leveling technique found here on ifixit .

Steps.Text_raw: I found it easier to reinstall the brown ribbon cable before the black one. Remember to tape the button in place when reassembling. I used these clips when I reattached the gimbal to test everything, before flying. If I had to go through and redo the ribbon cable connections it would have been easy to remove the gimbal with these in place. BE SURE TO USE NEW RETAINING CLIPS BEFORE FLYING!!! My camera still wasn't level. I had to use the camera leveling technique found here on iFixit.

Subject: Gimbal Yaw Arm

Lines.Text: with the battery facing you , locate the two tabs on the top and bottom of the battery as shown .
remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: With the battery facing you, locate the two tabs on the top and bottom of the battery as shown. Remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly.

Lines.Text: press the two tabs with your finger and thumb , and gently slide the battery towards you , out of the quadcopter frame .
with your other hand , be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still .

Steps.Text_raw: Press the two tabs with your finger and thumb, and gently slide the battery towards you, out of the quadcopter frame. With your other hand, be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still.

Lines.Text: turn the phantom 3 advanced upside down .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the Phantom 3 Advanced upside down.

Lines.Text: remove the four 7 mm long 2 mm screws with a t-6 screwdriver .
there is one screw per arm , located at the tip of the arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 7mm long 2mm screws with a T-6 screwdriver. There is one screw per arm, located at the tip of the arm.

Lines.Text: remove the eight 5 mm long 2.5 mm screws using the t-8 screwdriver .
there are two 5 mm screws on each arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eight 5mm long 2.5mm screws using the T-8 screwdriver. There are two 5mm screws on each arm.

Lines.Text: remove the four 10 mm long deep 3 mm screws using the t-8 screwdriver .
there is one screw on each arm located near the landing gear .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 10mm long deep 3mm screws using the T-8 screwdriver. There is one screw on each arm located near the landing gear.

Lines.Text: carefully flip the phantom back over with the motors facing up .
peel back the silver stickers from the seam in the cover .
using a plastic spudger , slowly separate the two halves of the plastic shell .
this step requires some force , and the plastic will click loudly as the shell separates .
do not fully remove the cover . there is a wire that needs to be detached from the control board before the cover is completely free .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully flip the phantom back over with the motors facing up. Peel back the silver stickers from the seam in the cover. Using a plastic spudger, slowly separate the two halves of the plastic shell. This step requires some force, and the plastic will click loudly as the shell separates. Do not fully remove the cover.  There is a wire that needs to be detached from the control board before the cover is completely free.

Lines.Text: slowly remove the upper half of the plastic case about halfway . there is a ribbon cable that's connects the cover and the control board .
follow the ribbon cable to the control board and locate the connector that connects the cable to the control board .
press the tab on the side of the connector and pull up on the cable .
continue to remove the shell the rest of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly remove the upper half of the plastic case about halfway. There is a ribbon cable that's connects the cover and the control board. Follow the ribbon cable to the control board and locate the connector that connects the cable to the control board. Press the tab on the side of the connector and pull up on the cable. Continue to remove the shell the rest of the way.

remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly .

with your other hand , be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still .

Lines.Text: turn the drone upside down with the motors facing the table .
unscrew the four 5.5 mm long 3 mm screws directly under the motor using a 2.0 mm hex bit screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the drone upside down with the motors facing the table. Unscrew the four 5.5mm long 3mm screws directly under the motor using a 2.0mm hex bit screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the glue that covers the three wires that connect the motor to the flight controller . use a plastic opening tool or a metal tool if needed .
repeat for each arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the glue that covers the three wires that connect the motor to the flight controller. Use a plastic opening tool or a metal tool if needed. Repeat for each arm.

Lines.Text: trace the black , yellow , and red wires from the motor to the flight controlle .
desolder the three wires where they connect to the flight controller . check out this desoldering guide to learn how to desolder : guide .
take out the motor and repeat for the other motors if needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Trace the black, yellow, and red wires from the motor to the flight controlle . Desolder the three wires where they  connect to the flight controller.  Check out this desoldering guide to learn how to desolder:  [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|Desoldering Guide]. Title: Boosted Board 1st Generation Remote Battery Replacement

Lines.Text: before disassembling your remote , be sure it is powered off .
remove the four 17.57 mm screws from the bottom of the case with a ph0 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling your remote, be sure it is powered off. Remove the four 17.57mm screws from the bottom of the case with a PH0 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: carefully separate the two halves of the casing by pulling them apart at the seam .
be sure to keep the scroll wheel , lever and buttons attached to the housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully separate the two halves of the casing by pulling them apart at the seam. Be sure to keep the scroll wheel, lever and buttons attached to the housing.

Lines.Text: remove the rectangular black adhesive foam on top of the battery by peeling it away from the battery .
desolder the battery connections from the circuit board .
replace the dead battery with a new 3.7 volt lithium polymer battery .
refer for more information how to desolder the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the rectangular black adhesive foam on top of the battery by peeling it away from the battery. Desolder the battery connections from the circuit board. Replace the dead battery with a new 3.7 volt lithium polymer battery. Refer [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|here] for more information how to desolder the battery.

Subject: Remote Battery

Title: DJI Phantom 3 Advanced Landing Gear Replacement

Lines.Text: with the battery facing you , locate the two tabs on the top and bottom of the battery as shown .
remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: With the battery facing you, locate the two tabs on the top and bottom of the battery as shown. Remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly.

Lines.Text: press the two tabs with your finger and thumb , and gently slide the battery towards you , out of the quadcopter frame .
with your other hand , be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still .

Steps.Text_raw: Press the two tabs with your finger and thumb, and gently slide the battery towards you, out of the quadcopter frame. With your other hand, be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still.

Lines.Text: turn the phantom upside down .
remove the eight 7.5 mm long 3 mm screws , securing the landing gear to the body of the quadcopter , with a t-8 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the phantom upside down. Remove the eight 7.5mm long 3mm screws, securing the landing gear to the body of the quadcopter, with a T-8 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the rubber spacer in the landing gear by pushing the spacer out of the slot with your finger .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the rubber spacer in the landing gear by pushing the spacer out of the slot with your finger.

Lines.Text: using a plastic opening tool , carefully separate the two pieces of plastic of the landing gear .
be careful not to break the wire attached , as this is your receiver antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a plastic opening tool, carefully separate the two pieces of plastic of the landing gear. Be careful not to break the wire attached, as this is your receiver antenna.

Lines.Text: feed the wire and attached plastic through the hole in the landing gear .

Title: Boosted Board 1st Generation Rear Wheels Replacement

Lines.Text: loosen the two 16.74 mm motor mount hex nut screws with a 9 /64 allen wrench .
do not remove the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the two 16.74 mm motor mount hex nut screws with a 9/64" Allen wrench. Do Not Remove the Screws.

Lines.Text: compress the motor mount back towards the wheel .
while keeping the motor mount compressed , tighten one of the hex nuts that you loosened in the previous step .
the motor mounts are spring tensioned so it is necessary compress them to loosen the belts .

Steps.Text_raw: Compress the motor mount back towards the wheel. While keeping the motor mount compressed, tighten one of the hex nuts that you loosened in the previous step. The motor mounts are spring tensioned so it is necessary compress them to loosen the belts.

Lines.Text: remove the axel nut with a 1 /2 socket wrench

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the axel nut with a 1/2" socket wrench

Lines.Text: rotate and pull counterclockwise until the wheel comes off the axle completely .
the''' front '''washer will come off with the wheel .
remove the '''back''' washer from the axle .
replacing the wheel requires the bearings to be switched into the new wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate and pull counterclockwise until the wheel comes off the axle completely. The''' front '''washer will come off with the wheel. Remove the '''back''' washer from the axle. Replacing the wheel requires the bearings to be switched into the new wheel.

while keeping the motor mount compressed , tighten one of the hex nuts that you loosened in the previous step .
the motor mounts are spring tensioned so it is necessary compress them to loosen the belts .

Lines.Text: compress the motor mount ++back++ .
slide the belt off the axle

Steps.Text_raw: Compress the motor mount ++back++ . Slide the belt off the axle

Lines.Text: remove the two hex screws .
remove the front hex screw .
when removing the front hex screw , ++hold the motor mount and the truck together++ .
the springs inside the motor mount will push the motor out of the casing if they are not held together .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two hex screws. Remove the front hex screw. When removing the Front hex screw, ++hold the motor mount and the truck together++. The springs inside the motor mount will push the motor out of the casing if they are not held together.

Lines.Text: making sure to hold the motor and truck together , lift off the belt casing and take off the belt .
do '''not''' let go of the motor and truck until the new belt is on and the ++front hex screw is tightened++ securely .
the springs inside the motor mount will push the motor out of the casing if they are not held together .

Steps.Text_raw: Making sure to hold the motor and truck together, lift off the belt casing and take off the belt. Do '''Not''' let go of the motor and truck until the new belt is on and the ++Front hex screw is tightened++ securely. The springs inside the motor mount will push the motor out of the casing if they are not held together.

Lines.Text: use one finger to pull out the pulley bearing .
a good technique is to go around in a circle and lift from underneath the bearing in a carving motion .

repeat step 7 for placing the bearing in this side of the wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the  red, yellow and black  wires that connect the LED to the control board. Check out the link below for more information on desoldering. [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|Desoldering Information]

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool and wedge it under the led .
press down on the plastic opening tool and remove the led .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool and wedge it under the LED. Press down on the plastic opening tool and remove the LED.

Lines.Text: with the battery facing you , locate the two tabs on the top and bottom of the battery as shown .
remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: With the battery facing you, locate the two tabs on the top and bottom of the battery as shown. Remember to disarm and power down your quadcopter before beginning any disassembly.

Lines.Text: press the two tabs with your finger and thumb , and gently slide the battery towards you , out of the quadcopter frame .
with your other hand , be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still .

Steps.Text_raw: Press the two tabs with your finger and thumb, and gently slide the battery towards you, out of the quadcopter frame. With your other hand, be sure to hold the quadcopter steady to ensure that it stays still.

Lines.Text: turn the phantom 3 advanced upside down .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the Phantom 3 Advanced upside down.

Lines.Text: remove the four 7 mm long 2 mm screws with a t-6 screwdriver .
there is one screw per arm , located at the tip of the arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 7mm long 2mm screws with a T-6 screwdriver. There is one screw per arm, located at the tip of the arm.

Lines.Text: remove the eight 5 mm long 2.5 mm screws using the t-8 screwdriver .
there are two 5 mm screws on each arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eight 5mm long 2.5mm screws using the T-8 screwdriver. There are two 5mm screws on each arm.

Lines.Text: remove the four 10 mm long deep 3 mm screws using the t-8 screwdriver .
there is one screw on each arm located near the landing gear .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 10mm long deep 3mm screws using the T-8 screwdriver. There is one screw on each arm located near the landing gear.

Lines.Text: carefully flip the phantom back over with the motors facing up .
peel back the silver stickers from the seam in the cover .
using a plastic spudger , slowly separate the two halves of the plastic shell .
this step requires some force , and the plastic will click loudly as the shell separates .
do not fully remove the cover . there is a wire that needs to be detached from the control board before the cover is completely free .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully flip the phantom back over with the motors facing up. Peel back the silver stickers from the seam in the cover. Using a plastic spudger, slowly separate the two halves of the plastic shell. This step requires some force, and the plastic will click loudly as the shell separates. Do not fully remove the cover.  There is a wire that needs to be detached from the control board before the cover is completely free.

Lines.Text: slowly remove the upper half of the plastic case about halfway . there is a ribbon cable that's connects the cover and the control board .
follow the ribbon cable to the control board and locate the connector that connects the cable to the control board .
press the tab on the side of the connector and pull up on the cable .
continue to remove the shell the rest of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly remove the upper half of the plastic case about halfway. There is a ribbon cable that's connects the cover and the control board. Follow the ribbon cable to the control board and locate the connector that connects the cable to the control board. Press the tab on the side of the connector and pull up on the cable. Continue to remove the shell the rest of the way.

Lines.Text: locate the five ribbon cables that need to be disconnected from the control board .
locate the red and black battery wires .
follow the three wires from each motor and the three wires from each led to where they connect on the control board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the five ribbon cables that need to be disconnected from the control board. Locate the red and black battery wires. Follow the three wires from each motor and the three wires from each LED to where they connect on the control board.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to remove the glue that covers the motor and led wires . use a metal opening tool if necessary .
desolder the six motor and led wires where they connect on the flight controller for each arm . refer to the guide on how to desolder .
desolder the battery wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to remove the glue that covers the motor and LED wires. Use a metal opening tool if necessary. Desolder the six motor and LED wires  where they connect on the flight controller for each arm.  Refer to the [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|Desoldering Guide] on how to desolder. Desolder the battery wires.

Lines.Text: remove the cable next to where the battery wires were connected . pinch and hold the top of the connector , then pull it out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cable next to where the battery wires were connected. Pinch and hold the top of the connector, then pull it out.

Lines.Text: remove the black ribbon cable and the 3-wire cable next to it . press the small tab on the ribbon cable connector and pull it out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the black ribbon cable and the 3-wire cable next to it. Press the small tab on the ribbon cable connector and pull it out.

Lines.Text: locate the ribbon cable that is next to the word front on the flight controller .
remove the small cable next to the ribbon cable by pinching on the side tab and pulling up on the connector . it has black , red and yellow wires .
remove the black band from the ribbon cable .
remove the ribbon cable by pinching on the side tab and pulling up on the connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the ribbon cable that is next to the word "Front" on the flight controller. Remove the small cable next to the ribbon cable by pinching on the side tab and pulling up on the connector. It has black, red and yellow wires. Remove the black band from the ribbon cable. Remove the ribbon cable by pinching on the side tab and pulling up on the connector.

Lines.Text: remove the four 6.5 mm long 2 mm screws with a phillips head 00 screwdriver .
remove the flight controller now by slowly pulling if off of the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 6.5mm long 2mm screws with a philips head 00 screwdriver. Remove the flight controller now by slowly pulling if off of the frame.

Title: Axa Security Greenline 50 LED Bike Headlight Disassembly
Category: Axa Security Greenline 50 LED Bike Headlight

Lines.Text: the key to opening the light's casing is to get rid of the black cover in the front . this is the part that covers up the screws you need to get to first . unfortunately , it has been glued on in a few spots , poor work axa ! it's best to use a stable plastic tool , so as not to break the plastic ( like i did ) .
also , start working from the side rather than from the front , so as not to scratch the lens .

Steps.Text_raw: The key to opening the light's casing is to get rid of the black cover in the front. This is the part that covers up the screws you need to get to first. Unfortunately, it has been glued on in a few spots, poor work Axa! It's best to use a stable plastic tool, so as not to break the plastic (like I did). Also, start working from the side rather than from the front, so as not to scratch the lens.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws that attach the lens to the metal cooler of the led

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws that attach the lens to the metal cooler of the LED

Lines.Text: this reveals the four screws holding the plastic back cover to the metal central chassis . remove them as well

Steps.Text_raw: This reveals the four screws holding the plastic back cover to the metal central chassis. Remove them as well

Lines.Text: the black one should be soldered to gnd
the red wire belongs where it says bat . +
now you can pull out the main circuit board , be careful not to tear off any more of the tiny wires . also , make sure you don't short circuit the lipo battery pack ( 1 s2 p 1000 mah )

the wires with transparent insulation are for the charging connector . after soldering everything back in its place , slide the board back into its slot on top of the battery . watch out for the tiny plastic bit of the on/off-button , that should be in its place in the orange silicon button-cover and tends to fall out .

don't use force to slide the board into the slot , otherwise you are likely to tear off one of the wires again . when everything is in place , test if you light works fine ( test light and charging ! ) before screwing everything together again .

at last , glue the black lens cover on again . don't use too much glue , in case you have to open the light later . also make sure you don't touch the lens with glue on your fingers ! a bit of scotch tape serves well as protection film until the glue is dry .

Steps.Text_raw: The black one should be soldered to "GND" The red wire belongs where it says "Bat.+" Now you can pull out the main circuit board, be careful not to tear off any more of the tiny wires. Also, make sure you don't short circuit the LiPo Battery pack (1s2P 1000mAh) The wires with transparent insulation are for the charging connector. After soldering everything back in its place, slide the board back into its slot on top of the battery. Watch out for the tiny plastic bit of the on/off-button, that should be in its place in the orange silicon button-cover and tends to fall out. Don't use force to slide the board into the slot, otherwise you are likely to tear off one of the wires again. When everything is in place, test if you light works fine (test light AND charging!) before screwing everything together again. At last, glue the black lens cover on again. Don't use too much glue, in case you have to open the light later. Also make sure you don't touch the lens with glue on your fingers! A bit of scotch tape serves well as protection film until the glue is dry.

Title: Suzuki DR650 SE membrane and seal replacement

Lines.Text: the two screws , here quite funny with a large phillips , or a 10-fork or ring spanner , unscrew .
very important : the tank should be at most 1 /4 full so that it does not leak . then you can put it upright .

Steps.Text_raw: The two screws, here quite funny with a large Phillips, or a 10-fork or ring spanner, unscrew. Very important: The tank should be at most 1/4 full so that it does not leak. Then you can put it upright.

Lines.Text: remove the 5 membrane cover screws with phillips ph2 and carefully remove the cover . caution here , the diaphragm spring pops out .
membrane
diaphragm spring
pellicle
check the seal kit and clean if necessary .
now remove the diaphragm with plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 5 membrane cover screws with Phillips PH2 and carefully remove the cover. Caution here, the diaphragm spring pops out. membrane diaphragm spring pellicle Check the seal kit and clean if necessary. Now remove the diaphragm with plate.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two phillips screws with a phillips ph2. then remove the actuator .
remove sealing plate and o-ring .
steller
spring washer
cover plate
now remove the foot seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two Phillips screws with a phillips PH2. Then remove the actuator. Remove sealing plate and O-ring. Steller spring washer cover plate Now remove the foot seal.

Lines.Text: remove the diaphragm . now we would have split everything up .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the diaphragm. Now we would have split everything up.

Lines.Text: membrane
membrane intermediate plate
diaphragm cover
diaphragm spring
fußdichtung
body
sealing plate

Steps.Text_raw: membrane Membrane intermediate plate diaphragm cover diaphragm spring Fußdichtung body sealing plate

Lines.Text: countersunk screws
steller
spring washer
o-ring
cover plate
head screws
and here is a representation of how the fuel cock works .

Steps.Text_raw: countersunk screws Steller spring washer O-ring cover plate Head Screws And here is a representation of how the fuel cock works.

Lines.Text: lightly grease the 3 gaskets . to remove the old seals , use the metal spudger . the new ones can be pressed in by hand .
sealing plate
and insert the o-ring into the body .

Steps.Text_raw: Lightly grease the 3 gaskets. To remove the old seals, use the metal spudger. The new ones can be pressed in by hand. sealing plate and insert the O-ring into the body.

Lines.Text: thread the spring washer and the cover plate into the actuator and build it into the base body . make sure that when screwing the spring ring is not pinched . one notices this when turning from on to res , when it comes to blocking , the spring washer is clamped . then stop again .

Steps.Text_raw: Thread the spring washer and the cover plate into the actuator and build it into the base body. Make sure that when screwing the spring ring is not pinched. One notices this when turning from "On" to "Res", when it comes to blocking, the spring washer is clamped. Then stop again.

Lines.Text: reinstall the new diaphragm in the intermediate plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Reinstall the new diaphragm in the intermediate plate.

Lines.Text: reinstall the diaphragm in the body .
place the spring in the center of the plate .
when reassembling , make sure the spring is exactly in the ring on the inside of the diaphragm cover , as the lock on the other side may be misaligned .

Steps.Text_raw: Reinstall the diaphragm in the body. Place the spring in the center of the plate. When reassembling, make sure the spring is exactly in the ring on the inside of the diaphragm cover, as the lock on the other side may be misaligned.

Lines.Text: re-screw the 5 phillips screws with a suitable phillips screwdriver ( ph2 ) .
gasoline connection
vacuum port

for functional testing , you must now apply a slight vacuum to the vacuum connection , which causes the cap to open . this can then be tested by blowing at the gasoline connection . when the vacuum drops , the shutter must close immediately .
now install the foot gasket .

Steps.Text_raw: Re-screw the 5 Phillips screws with a suitable Phillips screwdriver (PH2). gasoline connection Vacuum port For functional testing, you must now apply a slight vacuum to the vacuum connection, which causes the cap to open. This can then be tested by blowing at the gasoline connection. When the vacuum drops, the shutter must close immediately. Now install the foot gasket.

Lines.Text: now the fuel tap can be reinstalled .
be sure to install the two sealing washers under the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Now the fuel tap can be reinstalled. Be sure to install the two sealing washers under the screws.

Lines.Text: remove 3 9 mm screws around the motor housing . repeat the steps for the three other arms .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove 3 9mm screws around the motor housing. Repeat the steps for the three other arms.

Lines.Text: remove four 9 mm screws located where the legs originally are placed . ( use a thin head screwdriver )

Steps.Text_raw: Remove four 9 mm screws located where the legs originally are placed. (Use a thin head screwdriver)

Lines.Text: cut the yellow strips using a scalpel . pry open the casing using pry tools working gently around the corners .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the yellow strips using a scalpel. Pry open the casing using pry tools working gently around the corners.

Lines.Text: remove the motor assembly from the bottom shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motor assembly from the bottom shell.

Lines.Text: slide the pinion gear off of the motor assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the pinion gear off of the motor assembly.

Title: Parrot Bebop Drone GPS Board Replacement

Lines.Text: begin by removing the velcro strap around the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by removing the velcro strap around the battery.

Lines.Text: while holding onto the nose , gently pull the battery away from the nose .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding onto the nose, gently pull the battery away from the nose.

Lines.Text: once the battery is separated from the nose , push down on the connector and pull the battery away from the connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the battery is separated from the nose, push down on the connector and pull the battery away from the connector.

Lines.Text: remove the two 7 mm t5 torx screws using a screwdriver . there is one located on each side .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 7mm T5 torx  screws using a screwdriver. There is one located on each side.

Lines.Text: take the metal spudger , to remove the double stick tape from the foam .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the metal spudger, to remove the double stick tape from the foam.

Lines.Text: remove the styrofoam nose from over the drone's camera by sliding it towards the front of the drone at an angle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the styrofoam nose from over the drone's camera by sliding it towards the front of the drone at an angle.

Lines.Text: remove the cable from the top of the gps module .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cable from the top of the GPS module.

Lines.Text: remove the two 6 mm t5 torx screws holding the gps module . there is one screw on each side .
remove the 4 mm t5 screw holding the gps module .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 6mm T5 torx screws holding the GPS module. There is one screw on each side. Remove the  4mm T5 Screw holding the GPS Module.

Lines.Text: remove the gps board by lifting it off of the metal frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the GPS board by lifting it off of the metal frame.

Subject: GPS Board

Lines.Text: have someone hold the bicycle and handlebars steady throughout the fix .
if you have a workstand , use that to secure the bicycle .
roll back the brake hood cover on one of the handlebars .
pop out the bar plug at the end of the handlebar .

Steps.Text_raw: Have someone hold the bicycle and handlebars steady throughout the fix. If you have a workstand, use that to secure the bicycle. Roll back the brake hood cover on one of the handlebars. Pop out the bar plug at the end of the handlebar.

Lines.Text: typically , electrical tape is used to secure loose brake cables to the handlebars , then handlebar tape is wrapped around the entire handlebar , above the electrical tape , to create a cushion between the cyclist's hands and the handlebar .
the average handlebar tape kit will include at least two rolls of handlebar tape and at least two strips of electrical tape .
peel off the old handlebar tape entirely .
after removing the old handlebar tape , the old electrical tape securing the brake cables will be revealed .
remove the old electrical tape if it is not satisfactorily securing the brake cables .
apply new electrical tape to secure the brake cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Typically, electrical tape is used to secure loose brake cables to the handlebars, then handlebar tape is wrapped around the entire handlebar, above the electrical tape, to create a cushion between the cyclist's hands and the handlebar. The average handlebar tape kit will include at least two rolls of handlebar tape and at least two strips of electrical tape. Peel off the old handlebar tape entirely. After removing the old handlebar tape, the old electrical tape securing the brake cables will be revealed. Remove the old electrical tape if it is not satisfactorily securing the brake cables. Apply new electrical tape to secure the brake cables.

Lines.Text: cut one two-inch strip of bar tape from the roll , or use one of the two short strips found in the handlebar tape kit .
peel off the adhesive backing of the two-inch strip and affix it to the handlebar behind the brake lever clamp .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut one two-inch strip of bar tape from the roll, or use one of the two short strips found in the handlebar tape kit. Peel off the adhesive backing of the two-inch strip and affix it to the handlebar behind the brake lever clamp.

Lines.Text: peel off a few feet of the adhesive backing on the roll of new bar tape .
affix the center of the end of the tape to the edge of the drop bar so that half of the width of the tape hangs over the end of the bar .
begin to snugly wrap the tape up the handlebar , pulling the tape up and over the handlebar toward the bicycle .
as you wrap , peel off more adhesive backing as needed and overlap each new layer of tape by one half of its width .
when wrapping the tape around curves in the handlebars , allow for more overlap on the inside of the curve and less overlap on the outside of the curve .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off a few feet of the adhesive backing on the roll of new bar tape. Affix the center of the end of the tape to the edge of the drop bar so that half of the width of the tape hangs over the end of the bar. Begin to snugly wrap the tape up the handlebar, pulling the tape up and over the handlebar toward the bicycle. As you wrap, peel off more adhesive backing as needed and overlap each new layer of tape by one half of its width. When wrapping the tape around curves in the handlebars, allow for more overlap on the inside of the curve and less overlap on the outside of the curve.

Lines.Text: upon reaching the break lever clamp , wrap the tape under and around the handlebar , past the clamp .
continue wrapping towards the stem , pulling the tape up and over toward the back of the bicycle .

Steps.Text_raw: Upon reaching the break lever clamp, wrap the tape under and around the handlebar, past the clamp. Continue wrapping towards the stem, pulling the tape up and over toward the back of the bicycle.

Lines.Text: upon reaching the point at which you would like the bar tape to end ( typically a couple of inches out from the stem ) , cut the tape at a steep angle ( greater than 45 degrees ) toward the end of the bar .
finish wrapping the last few inches of bar tape .
optional : wrap a few layers of electrical tape around the end of the handlebar tape at the middle of the bar to decrease the chances of the handlebar tape peeling off .

Steps.Text_raw: Upon reaching the point at which you would like the bar tape to end (typically a couple of inches out from the stem), cut the tape at a steep angle (greater than 45 degrees) toward the end of the bar. Finish wrapping the last few inches of bar tape. Optional: Wrap a few layers of electrical tape around the end of the handlebar tape at the middle of the bar to decrease the chances of the handlebar tape peeling off.

Lines.Text: roll the brake hood cover back down over the newly-wrapped tape .
tuck the overhanging tape at the end of the bar into the plughole and push the bar plug back in .
repeat all previous steps for the other handlebar .

Steps.Text_raw: Roll the brake hood cover back down over the newly-wrapped tape. Tuck the overhanging tape at the end of the bar into the plughole and push the bar plug back in. Repeat all previous steps for the other handlebar.

Title: Protocol Dronium Two HD Camera Replacement

Lines.Text: turn device off by moving the selector switch to the left .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn device off by moving the selector switch to the left.

Lines.Text: place one hand on the drone and carefully remove the landing gear with the other hand .
be gentle as to not break off the studs on the landing gear .

Steps.Text_raw: Place one hand on the drone and carefully remove the landing gear with the other hand. Be gentle as to not break off the studs on the landing gear.

Lines.Text: use the fine edged plastic opening tool to pull up one side of the plug , and then the other , until it comes loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the fine edged plastic opening tool to pull up one side of the plug, and then the other, until it comes loose.

Lines.Text: push the battery cover away from the drone and carefully open it up .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the battery cover away from the drone and carefully open it up.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the two phillips 5.35 mm screws holding the camera to the battery cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the two Phillips 5.35 mm screws holding the camera to the battery cover.

Lines.Text: close the battery cover by pulling it towards you . then , gently pull the camera towards you , freeing it from the battery cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Close the battery cover by pulling it towards you. Then, gently pull the camera towards you, freeing it from the battery cover.

Subject: HD Camera

Toolbox.Name: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: the chain connects the crank arm to the gear cluster on the back wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: The chain connects the crank arm to the gear cluster on the back wheel.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: on the chain , locate the master chain . it is a lighter gray than the other links of the chain . this is how you can break the chain for easier removal .

Steps.Text_raw: On the chain, locate the master chain.  It is a lighter gray than the other links of the chain.  This is how you can break the chain for easier removal.

Lines.Text: to separate the master link , hold the left side of the link in your left hand and the link to the right in your right hand . push the two links together to enable the release . pull the links apart , one hand moving towards yourself and the other away from you . this will separate the links of the chain .

Steps.Text_raw: To separate the Master Link, hold the left side of the link in your left hand and the link to the right in your right hand.  Push the two links together to enable the release.  Pull the links apart, one hand moving towards yourself and the other away from you.  This will separate the links of the chain.

Lines.Text: once you have separated the links of the chain , pull down on the right side of the chain as shown . pull until the chain has been fully removed from the gears . place the chain on a paper towel or cloth to prevent getting grease anywhere .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have separated the links of the chain, pull down on the right side of the chain as shown.  Pull until the chain has been fully removed from the gears.  Place the chain on a paper towel or cloth to prevent getting grease anywhere.

Lines.Text: the crank arms can be located between the front and rear tire , directly below the seat .

Steps.Text_raw: The crank arms can be located between the front and rear tire, directly below the seat.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: to remove the crank arm , place a proper fitting allen wrench into the slot at the center of the crank arm as shown . turn the wrench counterclockwise to loosen the bolt that keeps the crank arm on the bike until it spins easily . hold the other crank arm in place to ensure that the bolt loosens instead of spinning the crank arm .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the crank arm, place a proper fitting Allen wrench into the slot at the center of the crank arm as shown.   Turn the wrench counterclockwise to loosen the bolt that keeps the crank arm on the bike until it spins easily.  Hold the other crank arm in place to ensure that the bolt loosens instead of spinning the crank arm.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: once the bolt spins easily , keep the allen wrench in the bolt slot and turn the crank arms to speed up the removal process .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the bolt spins easily, keep the Allen wrench in the bolt slot and turn the crank arms to speed up the removal process.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: remove the bolt from the crank arm . the crank arm will remain in place . do not try to pull off the crank arm , as a special tool is required for this task .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bolt from the crank arm.  The crank arm will remain in place.  Do not try to pull off the crank arm, as a special tool is required for this task.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: repeat steps 2-4 on the other crank arm . remember , do not try to pull off the crank arms .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat steps 2-4 on the other crank arm.  Remember, do not try to pull off the crank arms.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: obtain a crank puller tool . this tool has two parts , a movable threaded insert and the push bolt . screw the crank puller into the hole left by the bolt .

Steps.Text_raw: Obtain a crank puller tool.  This tool has two parts, a movable threaded insert and the push bolt.  Screw the crank puller into the hole left by the bolt.

Lines.Text: once the movable piece is tightened firmly inside the hole , turn the tool clockwise . this will pull the crank arm away from the bike and remove it completely .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the movable piece is tightened firmly inside the hole, turn the tool clockwise.  This will pull the crank arm away from the bike and remove it completely.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: repeat steps 6-7 with the remaining crank arm . both arms have been successfully removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat steps 6-7 with the remaining crank arm.   Both arms have been successfully removed.
Tools_extracted: park tool crank arm allen wrench

Lines.Text: the bottom bracket is located at the bottom of the frame , directly underneath the saddle .

Steps.Text_raw: The Bottom Bracket is located at the bottom of the frame, directly underneath the saddle.

Lines.Text: on the non-drive side , insert the bottom bracket removal tool into the splines on the inside of the bottom bracket mounting ring .
fit the crescent wrench onto the bottom bracket removal tool .
use the crescent wrench to turn the mounting ring counterclockwise until it is loose enough to turn by hand .

Steps.Text_raw: On the non-drive side, insert the bottom bracket removal tool into the splines on the inside of the bottom bracket mounting ring. Fit the crescent wrench onto the bottom bracket removal tool. Use the crescent wrench to turn the mounting ring counterclockwise until it is loose enough to turn by hand.
Tools_extracted: park tool bbt-22 bottom bracket removal tool

Lines.Text: turn the bottom bracket removal tool counterclockwise by hand until the mounting ring is free of the bicycle frame

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the bottom bracket removal tool counterclockwise by hand until the mounting ring is free of the bicycle frame
Tools_extracted: park tool bbt-22 bottom bracket removal tool

Lines.Text: fit the bottom bracket removal tool into the splines on the drive-side of the bottom bracket .
use the crescent wrench to turn the bottom bracket removal tool ''++clockwise++'' until the bottom bracket is loose enough to turn by hand .

Steps.Text_raw: Fit the bottom bracket removal tool into the splines on the drive-side of the bottom bracket. Use the crescent wrench to turn the bottom bracket removal tool ''++clockwise++'' until the bottom bracket is loose enough to turn by hand.

pull the bottom bracket out of the bike frame .

Lines.Text: to begin the repair remove the protective casing . ( this removal may vary with different lawnmowers . )

Steps.Text_raw: To begin the repair remove the protective casing. (This removal may vary with different lawnmowers.)

Lines.Text: locate the recoil housing cap .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the recoil housing cap.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the housing cap . ( removal may vary )

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the housing cap. (Removal may vary)

Lines.Text: after removing the recoil , unscrew the cap that holds the pulley to the recoil starter housing .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the recoil, unscrew the cap that holds the pulley to the recoil starter housing.

Lines.Text: untie the knot in the rope and slide it out of the housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Untie the knot in the rope and slide it out of the housing.

Lines.Text: with this particular model there is a middle lock piece . use a socket wrench to unscrew and release the coil .

Steps.Text_raw: With this particular model there is a middle lock piece. Use a socket wrench to unscrew and release the coil.

Lines.Text: once unscrewed , remove the metal piece which releases the tension on the coil .

Steps.Text_raw: Once unscrewed, remove the metal piece which releases the tension on the coil.

Lines.Text: at this point add the new coil to the housing base . snap the coil into position where the old on was .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point add the new coil to the housing base. Snap the coil into position where the old on was.

Title: 2004-2006 Honda Rancher 350 Four Wheeler Carburetor Repair

Lines.Text: press the latch on the back right side of the four wheeler seat to remove the seat .

Steps.Text_raw: Press the latch on the back right side of the four wheeler seat to remove the seat.

Lines.Text: as a safety precaution , use a phillips screwdriver to disconnect the negative battery terminal .
make sure you never disconnect the positive terminal of the battery before the negative terminal .

Steps.Text_raw: As a safety precaution, use a Phillips screwdriver to disconnect the negative battery terminal. Make sure you never disconnect the positive terminal of the battery before the negative terminal.

Lines.Text: use a ratchet with a 10 mm socket to loosen the clamp that connects the carburetor to the intake manifold .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a ratchet with a 10 mm socket to loosen the clamp that connects the carburetor to the intake manifold.

Lines.Text: use a flat blade screwdriver to pry and remove the rivets securing both of the side panels so that you will be able to easily access the carburetor .
there are about 10 rivets to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flat blade screwdriver to pry and remove the rivets securing both of the side panels so that you will be able to easily access the carburetor. There are about 10 rivets to remove.

Lines.Text: use a t30 torx screwdriver to remove the screw securing the black plastic panel on the left side of the four wheeler .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a T30 Torx screwdriver to remove the screw securing the black plastic panel on the left side of the four wheeler.

Lines.Text: use a wrench with a 10 mm socket to remove the hex bolt that secures the green plastic panel on the right side of the four wheeler .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a wrench with a 10 mm socket to remove the hex bolt that secures the green plastic panel on the right side of the four wheeler.

Lines.Text: be sure the fuel tank cutoff on the left side of the four wheeler is set to the off position before removing the gas line , or gas will spew out everywhere !
pull the gas line with your fingers to disconnect it from the engine .

Steps.Text_raw: Be sure the fuel tank cutoff on the left side of the four wheeler is set to the OFF position before removing the gas line, or gas will spew out everywhere! Pull the gas line with your fingers to disconnect it from the engine.

Lines.Text: remove the plastic rivet that connects the air-intake tube to the metal frame of the four wheeler .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic rivet that connects the air-intake tube to the metal frame of the four wheeler.

Lines.Text: pull the air-intake tube backwards away from the air filter box .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the air-intake tube backwards away from the air filter box.

Lines.Text: use a 10 mm socket wrench to remove the screw on the right hand side of the bottom of the black air filter box .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a 10 mm socket wrench to remove the screw on the right hand side of the bottom of the black air filter box.

Lines.Text: at this point , the black air filter box should be loose . lift the air filter box vertically out of the four wheeler .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point, the black air filter box should be loose. Lift the air filter box vertically out of the four wheeler.

Lines.Text: use your fingers to pull the gas line off of the carburetor .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers to pull the gas line off of the carburetor.

Lines.Text: use your fingers to disconnect the vacuum line from the carburetor .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers to disconnect the vacuum line from the carburetor.

Lines.Text: disconnect the electrical sensor connector located on the top frame of the right side of the four wheeler .
be gentle so you do not break the plastic connector .
you will probably have to pry the clip on the connector with a small flat blade screwdriver to separate the two halves of the connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the electrical sensor connector located on the top frame of the right side of the four wheeler. Be gentle so you do not break the plastic connector. You will probably have to pry the clip on the connector with a small flat blade screwdriver to separate the two halves of the connector.

Lines.Text: use a phillips screwdriver to remove the screw that secures the black cover on the right side of the carburetor .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips screwdriver to remove the screw that secures the black cover on the right side of the carburetor.

Lines.Text: twist the spring-loaded mechanism located underneath the black cover that was just removed in the previous step in order to loosen and slip the throttle cable out of the inside of the carburetor .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the spring-loaded mechanism located underneath the black cover that was just removed in the previous step in order to loosen and slip the throttle cable out of the inside of the carburetor.

Lines.Text: remove the choke cable attached to the carburetor by twisting the carburetor around to unscrew it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the choke cable attached to the carburetor by twisting the carburetor around to unscrew it.

Lines.Text: at this point , the carburetor should be fully disconnected . lift the carburetor up out of the four wheeler and gently place it on a table where it can be further disassembled .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point, the carburetor should be fully disconnected. Lift the carburetor up out of the four wheeler and gently place it on a table where it can be further disassembled.

Lines.Text: use the phillips screwdriver to remove the two screws holding the primer assembly on the carburetor .
when you take this screw out , be careful that you do not lose the spring underneath it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the Phillips screwdriver to remove the two screws holding the primer assembly on the carburetor. When you take this screw out, be careful that you do not lose the spring underneath it.

Lines.Text: use a phillips screwdriver to unscrew the four screws that secure the top metal cover of the carburetor , and remove the cover .
after you remove the metal cover , pull out the spring and rubber bellows that was underneath it .
be sure to remember the position of the vacuum holder highlighted in the picture so that you can put it back in the same position later .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips screwdriver to unscrew the four screws that secure the top metal cover of the carburetor, and remove the cover. After you remove the metal cover, pull out the spring and rubber bellows that was underneath it. Be sure to remember the position of the vacuum holder highlighted in the picture so that you can put it back in the same position later.

Lines.Text: use a phillips screwdriver to remove the four screws that secure the float-bowl assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips screwdriver to remove the four screws that secure the float-bowl assembly.

Lines.Text: use a punch or small flat blade screwdriver to drive out the pin holding the float and lift the float out .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a punch or small flat blade screwdriver to drive out the pin holding the float and lift the float out.

Lines.Text: thoroughly spray the disassembled carburetor pieces with super clean and scrub everything with a toothbrush .
rinse the parts with water from a garden hose .

Steps.Text_raw: Thoroughly spray the disassembled carburetor pieces with Super Clean and scrub everything with a toothbrush. Rinse the parts with water from a garden hose.

Lines.Text: use an air compressor to blow air through all of the openings in the carburetor to dry it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an air compressor to blow air through all of the openings in the carburetor to dry it.

Lines.Text: thoroughly spray carburetor cleaner all over the outside , inside , and openings of the carburetor .
be careful not to get carburetor cleaner on your skin or eyes or breathe it in .

Steps.Text_raw: Thoroughly spray carburetor cleaner all over the outside, inside, and openings of the carburetor. Be careful not to get carburetor cleaner on your skin or eyes or breathe it in.

Lines.Text: unscrew and replace the idle speed adjustment screw and spring provided in the carburetor kit .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew and replace the idle speed adjustment screw and spring provided in the carburetor kit.

Lines.Text: use a flat blade screwdriver to unscrew and replace the idle air adjustment needle along with its rubber o-rings provided in the carburetor kit .

be sure to take note of the number of turns that the screw is initially screwed in , as this is the factory adjusted idle air for the four wheeler ; you will want to put this screw in the exact same position when you screw the new needle in .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flat blade screwdriver to unscrew and replace the idle air adjustment needle along with its rubber o-rings provided in the carburetor kit. Be sure to take note of the number of turns that the screw is initially screwed in, as this is the factory adjusted idle air for the four wheeler; you will want to put this screw in the exact same position when you screw the new needle in.

Lines.Text: use a flat blade screwdriver to unscrew and replace the carburetor jet provided in the carburetor kit .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flat blade screwdriver to unscrew and replace the carburetor jet provided in the carburetor kit.

Lines.Text: use a flat blade screwdriver to unscrew and replace the orifice highlighted in the photo .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flat blade screwdriver to unscrew and replace the orifice highlighted in the photo.

use pliers to re-attach the float to the carburetor by pressing in the float pin .

Lines.Text: make sure the hoverboard is completely powered off and unplugged from any outlets .
flip the swagtron so that the footpads are facing the ground .
unscrew the sixteen 9.4 mm phillips 1 machine screws on the side of the swagtron that is now facing upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the hoverboard is completely powered off and unplugged from any outlets. Flip the Swagtron so that the footpads are facing the ground. Unscrew the sixteen 9.4 mm Phillips #1 machine screws on the side of the Swagtron that is now facing upwards.

Lines.Text: be careful with the small blue capacitors indicated by the orange box . there are many of these capacitors in the device .
slowly lift the backside cover .
both sides lift up the same way , but the motherboard is under one side and the battery is under the other .
detach the four cables connected to the cover by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables out :
three cables on the motherboard side .
two red cables with white connectors and one white cable with a white connector .
one yellow cable with a black connector on the battery side .
after detachment , you should be able to completely remove the backside cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful with the small blue capacitors indicated by the orange box.  There are many of these capacitors in the device. Slowly lift the backside cover. Both sides lift up the same way, but the motherboard is under one side and the battery is under the other. Detach the four cables connected to the cover by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables out: Three cables on the motherboard side. Two red cables with white connectors and one white cable with a white connector. One yellow cable with a black connector on the battery side. After detachment, you should be able to completely remove the backside cover.

Lines.Text: detach the two cables connecting the battery to the swagtron by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables apart :
one red and black cable with a yellow connector .
one blue cable with a black connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Detach the two cables connecting the battery to the Swagtron by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables apart: One red and black cable with a yellow connector. One blue cable with a black connector.

Lines.Text: remove the battery by pulling it out from under the cables .

detach the four cables connecting the gyroscope to the hoverboard by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables out :
three red and black cables with white connectors .
one multicolored cable with a black connector .

Lines.Text: uncrew the four 7.2 mm phillips 1 self-drilling screws connecting the blue gyroscope to the white plastic holding piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Uncrew the four 7.2 mm Phillips #1 self-drilling screws connecting the blue gyroscope to the white plastic holding piece.

Lines.Text: cut the plastic cable tie holding the cables together with utility scissors .
disconnect the blue/green cable from the blue/white cable by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the plastic cable tie holding the cables together with utility scissors. Disconnect the blue/green cable from the blue/white cable by pinching the connector clips and pulling the cables apart.

Lines.Text: gently lift the blue gyroscope off of the white plastic holder piece .
after reassembling the swagtron with the new gyroscope , check to make sure your swagtron is balancing properly .
if it is still unbalanced , repeat all steps in this guide with the gyroscope by the other wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the blue gyroscope off of the white plastic holder piece. After reassembling the Swagtron with the new gyroscope, check to make sure your Swagtron is balancing properly. If it is still unbalanced, repeat all steps in this guide with the gyroscope by the other wheel.

flip the swagtron so that the footpads are facing the ground .
unscrew the sixteen 9.4 mm phillips 1 machine screws on the side of the swagtron that is now facing upwards .
